Additionally, physical Arceus-Ground benefits from the presence of the more common defensive and Calm Mind Arceus-Ground sets, as it is able to beat switch-ins expecting to check other Arceus-Ground sets such as Primal Kyogre and Palkia-O.
  • Dragon Dance is Arceus-Ground's primary boosting move. Alternatively, Swords Dance is a viable option, as Sticky Web support enables Arceus-Ground to outspeed the entire unboosted metagame with the exception of specially offensive Yveltal.
  • Arceus-Ground's last moveslot should be tailored to best support its team. On hyper offense teams, Taunt prevents Pokemon such as Giratina-O and Yveltal from removing entry hazards while also protecting Arceus-Ground from status moves. Recover enables Arceus-Ground to perform the defensive duties expected of it on bulky offense teams, such as switching into Primal Groudon multiple times while remaining healthy enough to sweep late-game. Healing Wish is also an option on hyper offense teams to give a teammate such as Zacian-C or Ultra Necrozma a second chance at sweeping.
  • As Ultra Necrozma is a staple on hyper offense teams, Arceus-Ground typically equips an Earth Plate. However, bulky offense teams appreciate Arceus-Ground's ability to OHKO Dragon Dance Necrozma-DM and wallbreaker Primal Kyogre after Stealth Rock with Tectonic Rage. Arceus-Ground's ability to OHKO defensive Primal Groudon and utility Arceus formes with Tectonic Rage after a Swords Dance is appreciated by many Sticky Web teams.
  • The given EV spread maximizes Arceus-Ground's mixed bulk while allowing it to outspeed Primal Groudon and maximize damage output. This ensures that it outspeeds most of the defensive metagame and can revenge kill Pokemon such as Primal Groudon and Primal Kyogre. The defensive investment prevents Arceus-Ground from being OHKOed by Necrozma-DM's Searing Sunraze Smash, Life Orb Deoxys-A's Psycho Boost, and after a layer of Spikes, Choice Band Rayquaza's Dragon Ascent, Choice Band Melmetal's Double Iron Bash, and Choice Specs Eternatus's Draco Meteor. Arceus-Ground also survives Tectonic Rage and +1 Tera Ground Earthquake from opposing Arceus-Ground.
  • Tera Ground enables Arceus-Ground to OHKO some targets without a boost, such as Dragon Dance Necrozma-DM after a single layer of Spikes and defensive Primal Groudon after Stealth Rock and a layer of Spikes. Tera Rock is an alternate option to OHKO switch-ins such as Mega Salamence switching in on a Dragon Dance after Stealth Rock with Stone Edge. At +1, Tera Rock Stone Edge OHKOes defensive Yveltal and 2HKOes Giratina-O after Stealth Rock. Tera Rock can also be used defensively to resist common priority move such as Arceus's and Rayquaza's Extreme Speed.
  • On hyper offense teams, Arceus-Ground is best used as a mid-game wallbreaker to remove Pokemon such as Primal Groudon, Ho-Oh, and Necrozma-DM. On bulky offense teams, it is best used early-game due to its positive matchups against both common hazard setters such as Primal Groudon and Defoggers such as Ho-Oh and Yveltal. Arceus-Ground should be kept reasonably healthy, as it is often able to sweep late-game after a boost. It also struggles against stall teams, as it is walled by Dondozo and phazed by Giratina-O, though Taunt is disruptive to many stall teams.
  • Shuckle is a great Sticky Web user to enable Swords Dance Arceus-Ground. Kyurem-B synergizes well with Arceus-Ground, as it is able to break through Dondozo and exploit Tera Grass Ho-Oh, which walls Arceus-Ground. Zacian-C also appreciates Arceus-Ground's efficacy in removing Primal Groudon and Ho-Oh while helping against Arceus-Dark. Specially offensive Yveltal is also a great partner that threatens most of the defensive metagame and dissuades Ditto from using Earthquake after copying Arceus-Ground.
  • On bulky offense teams, utility Swords Dance Primal Groudon provides Stealth Rock support and a switch-in to Primal Kyogre, which scares out an unboosted Arceus-Ground. Choice Band Marshadow is an excellent teammate that is able to revenge kill Pokemon such as Ultra Necrozma and Zacian-C, which threaten a chipped Arceus-Ground.

Defensive.description:
• Arceus-Ground covers a wide variety of foes and utility roles, thanks to its solid mixed bulk and wide movepool. Its typing hits some of the most relevant threats in the metagame super effectively while also giving it few weaknesses and relevant resistances, allowing it to answer a variety of foes such as Primal Groudon, Necrozma-DM, Eternatus, and Yveltal and turning it into a versatile pick for a wide variety of team structures.
  • Toxic allows Arceus-Ground to hinder switch-ins immune to Judgment like Ho-Oh, Giratina-O, Mega Salamence, and Yveltal; Ice Beam alternatively complements Judgment to hit all previously mentioned foes but Ho-Oh, as well as Zygarde, super effectively. Taunt prevents entry hazards from Primal Groudon, Necrozma-DM, and Ferrothorn, Defog from Ho-Oh and Giratina-O, disruptive moves such as Glare, Toxic, and Will-O-Wisp from Zygarde, Yveltal, and Giratina-O, and setup and recovery moves from Zygarde, Primal Groudon, and Necrozma-DM, rendering them easier to beat.
  • Stealth Rock provides general utility to support the rest of Arceus-Ground's team, helping wallbreaking allies such as Primal Groudon and Zacian-C to net more OHKOs as they force switches.
  • The given EV spread avoids a 2HKO from Life Orb Marshadow's Low Kick after Stealth Rock and a 2HKO from Zacian-C's Play Rough after Intrepid Sword and Stealth Rock. The Speed investment ensures Arceus-Ground outspeeds fully invested Primal Groudon, and the remaining EVs are used on Special Attack to raise the odds to OHKO Zacian-C and Zekrom after Stealth Rock with Judgment.
  • Arceus-Ground is a Pokemon that doesn't Terastallize often, as its allies usually make better use of the mechanic. Tera Poison renders it unable to check Ground-types such as Primal Groudon, opposing Arceus-Ground, and Zygarde and makes it weaker to Stealth Rock. However, Tera Poison raises the accuracy of Toxic, increases Arceus-Ground's longevity by making it immune to Toxic itself from foes such as Giratina-O, Ho-Oh, and Yveltal, enables it to wall further foes such as Marshadow and Eternatus, and lets it absorb Eternatus's Toxic Spikes, supporting its team with entry hazard control.
  • Arceus-Ground's special bulk can be too lacking at times to handle foes such as Mega Mewtwo Y and Lunala; as such, it appreciates partners to make a defensive core with, such as Ho-Oh, Necrozma-DM, and Yveltal. Water-types such as Primal Kyogre, Palkia-O, and Arceus-Water can easily break past Arceus-Ground; therefore, it appreciates Pokemon on its side like Primal Groudon, Eternatus, and Ferrothorn to handle them.
  • Wallbreakers that can break past foes Arceus-Ground can't do much against on its own are valuable to ease progress. For example, Zacian-C threatens Giratina-O and Mega Mewtwo Y for Arceus-Ground sets without Toxic, Primal Kyogre covers Ho-Oh and Zygarde for variants without both Ice Beam and Toxic, and Marshadow can make progress against Ho-Oh, Giratina-O, and Primal Groudon independently of Arceus-Ground's set, especially with Stealth Rock support from Arceus-Ground to wear down the other team.

Utility.description:
• Arceus-Rock's unique typing and access to Will-O-Wisp allow it to carve out a niche as a check to foes such as Extreme Killer Arceus, Mega Salamence, and Rayquaza while putting pressure on common Defoggers like Ho-Oh and crippling would-be checks like Necrozma-DM and Zygarde with Will-O-Wisp.
  • Will-O-Wisp allows Arceus-Rock to check Extreme Killer Arceus, Mega Salamence, and Rayquaza more effectively and lets it cripple other physical attackers, such as Calyrex-I and Zekrom. It also greatly annoys common Rock-resistant Pokemon, such as Zygarde, Zacian-C, Necrozma-DM, and Arceus-Ground.
  • Stealth Rock is a good option, since Arceus-Rock threatens common Defoggers like Ho-Oh and Yveltal, keeping it up consistently. Taunt lets Arceus-Rock deny foes' attempts to recover health or spread status. Refresh lets Arceus-Rock shrug off Toxic and burns from Ho-Oh, defensive Eternatus, and Arceus-Dark. Ice Beam can be ran in the third slot to lure in and catch Zygarde off guard.
  • The given EV spread enables Arceus-Rock to avoid a 2HKO from specially offensive Yveltal's Dark Pulse, avoid an OHKO from +1 Adamant Mega Salamence's Earthquake after Stealth Rock, and almost always avoid an OHKO from +1 Life Orb Rayquaza's Earthquake while having enough Speed to outpace Chi-Yu. The rest of the EVs are invested to OHKO defensive Ho-Oh.
  • Tera Rock lets Arceus-Rock fire off more powerful Judgments, notably letting it OHKO defensive Yveltal and 2HKO defensive Primal Groudon, offensive Eternatus, and offensive Primal Kyogre after Stealth Rock, while retaining its ability to check Extreme Killer Arceus, Mega Salamence and Rayquaza. Tera Grass can also be used to turn its weaknesses to Ground and Water into resistances, providing defensive insurance for Zygarde, Arceus-Ground, and Primal Kyogre.
  • Arceus-Rock should be used aggressively to chip the opposing team with STAB Judgment, which is difficult to switch into, while burning the opposing Rock-resistant foes, such as Zacian-C and Marshadow, and pressuring common forms of hazard control. This role is expanded upon when facing Extreme Killer Arceus, Rayquaza, Ho-Oh, Yveltal, and Mega Salamence, in which case Arceus-Rock should be preserved to check these threats.
  • Arceus-Rock appreciates teammates like Yveltal, Ho-Oh, and Eternatus that cover its numerous weaknesses to common moves, such as Arceus-Ground's Earthquake and Kyogre's Origin Pulse, while they, in turn, appreciate Arceus-Rock's ability to check strong physical attackers like Extreme Killer Arceus and Mega Salamence.
  • Running Stealth Rock on Arceus-Rock can allow Primal Groudon to run more offensive sets. Pokemon that appreciate Arceus-Rock burning Steel-types, such as Eternatus, Zacian-C, and Mega Salamence, are good partners, as they can set up more easily. Mega Salamence is especially good to pair with, as it checks Primal Groudon and Primal Kyogre offensively and can use a burned Necrozma-DM lacking status moves as setup fodder.
  • Arceus-Rock and Gothitelle make a good pairing, since Arceus-Rock can burn physical attackers such as Zygarde, Necrozma-DM, and Dragon Dance Arceus-Ground to make Gothitelle's trapping more consistent; in turn, Gothitelle takes out these Ground- and Steel-types that threaten Arceus-Rock.

Defensive Calm Mind.description:
• Arceus-Water's excellent typing, supplemented by superb natural bulk, is attractive to balance teams looking for a sweeper that also contributes defensively as a switch-in to specially offensive Yveltal, a Pokemon balance teams lacking Arceus-Fairy notoriously struggle with, while also scaring out Ho-Oh.
  • As Judgment, Calm Mind, and Recover are all mandatory, Arceus-Water only has one moveslot left for coverage. Unfortunately, there is no singular move that perfectly complements Judgment, leaving Arceus-Water reliant on teammates to handle certain Pokemon it does not have coverage for. Ice Beam enables Arceus-Water to hit Pokemon that would otherwise wall it such as Mega Salamence, Rayquaza, and Giratina-O while ensuring Primal Groudon does not switch in freely. Alternatively, Earth Power heavily punishes Primal Groudon attempting to freely switch in on Judgment while preventing Arceus-Water from being walled by Water-types such as Primal Kyogre and opposing Arceus-Water.
  • The given EV spread ensures that Arceus-Water outspeeds fully invested neutral-natured base 90 Speed Pokemon such as Primal Groudon and Primal Kyogre. Furthermore, the high investment in bulk enables Arceus-Water to survive some monstrously powerful attacks including Basculegion's Last Respects after five fainted allies, +3 Zacian-C's Wild Charge, Deoxys-A's Psycho Boost after Stealth Rock, and Tera Flying Choice Band Rayquaza's Dragon Ascent after Stealth Rock and a single layer of Spikes. Additionally, Arceus-Water avoids the 2HKO from Double Dance Primal Groudon's Precipice Blades and Choice Band Marshadow's Low Kick.
  • Though Arceus-Water rarely Terastallizes, it can still effectively utilize its Tera type in a pinch to help flip certain matchups or to facilitate a sweep. Tera Fairy transforms Arceus-Water from a passable to sturdy specially offensive Yveltal check while retaining a stellar defensive typing and becoming a good Marshadow check. Tera Poison is an alternate option that enables Arceus-Water to more consistently sweep bulkier balance teams. The newfound Toxic immunity enables Arceus-Water to switch into Ho-Oh and defensive Eternatus with impunity and use them as setup fodder. Absorbing Eternatus's Toxic Spikes has the added benefit of alleviating pressure on teammates to use Defog. However, Arceus-Water's new weakness to the omnipresent Ground-type attacks from Primal Groudon and Arceus-Ground means that Tera Poison should be used cautiously.
  • Arceus-Water excels against balance and bulky offense teams. It has a strong mid-game presence, as it prevents Ho-Oh, defensive Yveltal, and—if Arceus-Water runs Ice Beam—Giratina-O from freely removing entry hazards. However, Arceus-Water should do so cautiously, as all three commonly run Toxic, which can prevent Arceus-Water from sweeping in the end-game. Arceus-Water lacks the ability to make progress against stall teams and is overwhelmed by hyper offense teams due to a lack of power before boosting.
  • As Arceus-Water has coverage issues regardless of whether it runs Ice Beam or Earth Power, it relies on teammates to fill these gaps. Zygarde is an excellent choice as a blanket physical wall that checks Pokemon such as Primal Groudon, Rayquaza, and Mega Salamence. Zygarde also alleviates pressure on Arceus-Water defensively, which enables it to more consistently sweep. In return, Arceus-Water checks Taunt Arceus-Ground and specially offensive Yveltal, which shut down Zygarde. Ferrothorn is also an excellent teammate due to checking wallbreaker Primal Kyogre, which can easily run through many balance teams, especially if a Timid nature is used. Arceus-Water also appreciates offensive partners such as Choice Band Marshadow and specially offensive Yveltal, which thrive against the hyper offense and stall teams that Arceus-Water struggles with due to their ability to revenge kill Pokemon such as Zacian-C, Mega Salamence, and Ultra Necrozma.

Offensive Calm Mind.description:
• With access to Calm Mind and excellent base 120 stats across the board, Arceus-Water is able to act as a strong bulky setup sweeper.
  • Arceus-Water's good typing allows it to break through defensive staples such as Ho-Oh and Arceus-Ground while dealing great damage to Zygarde.
  • Calm Mind allows Arceus-Water to 2HKO walls like Necrozma-DM and Primal Groudon. Aside from boosting Arceus-Water's Special Attack, it also allows it to turn the tables on some switch-ins that typically check it such as Eternatus and Palkia-O; in conjunction with Recover, it provides Arceus-Water with the longevity needed to continuously take on strong special attacks from foes like Eternatus and offensive Yveltal in order to set up on them.
  • Earth Power enables Arceus-Water to threaten foes that can take Water-type moves, 2HKOing Primal Groudon and Eternatus at +1. Grass Knot can also be used instead of Earth Power to hit heavy Water-types like Primal Kyogre, Palkia-O, and opposing Arceus-Water.
  • Arceus-Water's choice of Tera type is determined by the coverage move it runs. Tera Ground boosts Earth Power to muscle through Primal Groudon and Zacian-C with an OHKO on both at +1 whilst granting it an immunity to Electric-type attacks from Zekrom and Primal Kyogre. Tera Grass is used to power up Grass Knot, and at +1 it has a chance to OHKO Primal Kyogre and deal significant damage to Zygarde whilst resisting its Ground-type STAB moves and the aforementioned Electric-type Arceus-Water best fits on bulky and hyper offense teams that appreciate its great bulk and typing.
  • It is preferable to use Arceus-Water early-game to blow holes into the opposing team's defensive core, as it can easily use Calm Mind on the likes of Ho-Oh and Zygarde and force progress, which is appreciated by teammates such as Necrozma-DM and offensive Primal Groudon. It also has good synergy with the aforementioned teammates, as it helps them beat physical walls like Zygarde and opposing Primal Groudon.
  • Although Arceus-Water has good Special Attack, it struggles to beat special walls such as Chansey, Ferrothorn, and Giratina, so teammates like Primal Groudon, Marshadow, and Zacian-C are appreciated.
  • Fairy-types like Zacian-C help Arceus-Water deal with Dragon-type foes, as it struggles to deal damage to foes such as Ultra Necrozma, Mega Salamence, and Rayquaza. In return, Arceus-Water can beat foes such as Primal Groudon and Ho-Oh for them.

Calm Mind + Refresh.description:
• Calm Mind Arceus-Water is already a potent sweeper by itself, and with the addition of Refresh, it can be almost impossible to stop once it gets going, beating traditional checks like Giratina-O and Eternatus. The one caveat of this set is its inability to hit Primal Groudon at all, requiring the team to be built around hitting it with Toxic or easily removing it. Furthermore, this set does not forgo Arceus-Water’s defensive utility, as it still checks Necrozma-DM and Ho-Oh, and the set even expands on its utility with the addition of Refresh enabling it to become a status absorber.
  • Calm Mind functions both as a defensive tool and an offensive one, letting Arceus-Water actually pressure Zygarde and Eternatus while also setting itself up for a sweep late-game.
  • Refresh lets Arceus-Water shrug off Toxic from Ho-Oh and Eternatus, utilizing them as setup fodder, and freely pivot into Necrozma-DM without worrying about being statused.
  • The given EV spread with a Timid nature lets Arceus-Water outspeed Modest Palkia-O and offensive Yveltal, allowing it to use Calm Mind or Recover before it can throw off an attack, with the remainder of the EVs dumped in Defense to maximize its defensive utility; this notably lets it avoid the KO from +2 Searing Sunraze Smash from Necrozma-DM after Stealth Rock and +1 Tectonic Rage from Arceus Ground.
  • Tera Fairy gives Arceus-Water a better defensive typing that prevents it from being phazed by Dragon Tail Zygarde and Giratina-O, lets it swtch into non-Sludge Bomb Eternatus better, and prevents it from being forced out by non-Behemoth Blade Zacian-C. As Arceus-Water doesn't require Terastallizing often to sweep, Tera Fairy is mainly used to enhance its defensive role if it is unable to sweep, letting it check Life Orb Yveltal and Marshadow better.
  • Calm Mind + Refresh Arceus-Water should always be paired with a teammate that can either lure or put immense pressure on Primal Groudon. Arceus-Water is best used mid- or late-game, as its defensive utility allows it to stave off threats like Dragon Dance Necrozma-DM and Palkia O, and it can sweep once Primal Groudon is poisoned or removed. If Primal Groudon cannot be removed or hit by Toxic easily, then Arceus-Water can be relegated to a more defensive role throughout the match and absorb status for its teammates safely; in a pinch, it can Tera to check a wider array of threats. Shuca Berry Eternatus is the most notable example, as it lures in Primal Groudon and poisons it, essentially allowing Arceus-Water to set up on it freely and win. Primal Kyogre is also a great partner, as it constantly forces in and pressures Primal Groudon and Eternatus, which can heavily annoy Arceus-Water. Zacian-C functions similarly to wear down Primal Groudon throughout a game or even outright remove it with Tera Blast Ground.
  • Gothitelle is also a notable partner that can trap and remove defensive Primal Groudon lacking Overheat, but it struggles against offensive variants and defensive ones with Overheat. As such, additional support is needed alongside it, such as Toxic Spikes or Dragonium Z Eternatus. Zygarde is also great alongside Arceus-Water, as it checks Primal Groudon consistently while also appreciating Arceus-Water checking Kyogre and offensive Yveltal for it.

Choice Scarf.description:
• Galarian Darmanitan makes for a strong yet niche revenge killer against top threats such as Zacian-C, Eternatus, Arceus-Ground, and Deoxys-A for balance and bulky offense teams. It also assists its teammates with U-turn support, making it a solid source of speed control. However, its Stealth Rock weakness limits its overall longevity and makes it weaker to priority moves from Marshadow and Arceus, which other speed control options such as Pheromosa do not have to deal with, and it is often setup fodder for Pokemon such as Tera Water Zygarde, defensive Primal Kyogre, and Alomomola. This means that Galarian Darmanitan is mostly used to strengthen the team against opposing offense matchups, rather than being consistent into other structures such as fat balance or stall.
  • Earthquake complements Icicle Crash nicely, hitting the Steel- and Fire-types, such as Necrozma-DM, Zacian-C, and Chi-Yu, that resist the latter while also hitting Primal Groudon super effectively. Rock Slide is necessary to prevent Ho-Oh from scouting Galarian Darmanitan's chosen move and cleanly OHKO it, which is very useful for Galarian Darmanitan's teammates to capitalize on afterwards. U-turn is necessary for pivoting against foes Galarian Darmanitan cannot handle, which is needed early-game against healthy Primal Groudon, Zygarde, Ho-Oh, and support Arceus formes. Flare Blitz can be considered over Earthquake, notably for being able to OHKO Zacian-C more reliably while also OHKOing Ferrothorn and Calyrex-I after Stealth Rock. However, the recoil combined with Galarian Darmanitan's weakness to Stealth Rock; its inability to hit Water-types, notably offensive Primal Kyogre; and its inability to hit Primal Groudon super effectively makes this rarely worthwhile, especially because Ferrothorn is already at risk of being 2HKOed by Icicle Crash.
  • Tera Ground not only removes Galarian Darmanitan's Stealth Rock weakness but also bolsters Earthquake's power to new heights. It notably gives Earthquake a chance to OHKO Dragon Dance Necrozma-DM and offensive Primal Kyogre after Stealth Rock, more reliably OHKOes Zacian-C and Eternatus, and is useful against Tera Fire variants of Eternatus.
  • Galarian Darmanitan works best on bulky offense structures where its ability to pivot and prevent setup sweepers from getting out of hand is valued. Due to its horrendous bulk, Galarian Darmanitan works best as a revenge killer and should only come in after a fainted ally or a slow pivot such as Landorus-T, after which it can safely remove an offensive threat like Zacian-C or Eternatus.
  • Outside of hyper offense matchups, Galarian Darmanitan works best as a cleaner rather than a wallbreaker. The latter role is performed much better by other offensive Ice-types such as Chien-Pao and Kyurem-B, but Galarian Darmanitan's higher Speed and unresisted coverage allow it to make quick work of opposing teams in the late-game after offensive pressure from teammates such as Eternatus and Primal Groudon have worn down would-be checks such as Necrozma-DM or Ho-Oh. Galarian Darmanitan can also be used as a lead thanks to its fast U-turn, but switch-ins to other common leads such as Primal Groudon and Arceus-Ground are necessary, making Giratina-O and Ho-Oh fantastic partners.
  • Eternatus is one of Galarian Darmanitan's best partners; offensive sets, such as Meteor Beam and Choice Specs, are able to break through physical walls such as Zygarde and Primal Groudon, with Meteor Beam sets sniping Ho-Oh too, making Galarian Darmanitan harder to pivot into with its colorful coverage. Eternatus may also encourage Ho-Oh to use Tera Grass to avoid being OHKOed by Meteor Beam, opening itself up to Galarian Darmanitan afterwards. Meanwhile, defensive sets utilize Toxic Spikes to slowly wear down foes, allowing Galarian Darmanitan to easily clean up afterwards thanks to all the switches it forces. In return, Galarian Darmanitan is able to revenge kill Zacian-C and Deoxys-A and wear down Necrozma-DM, all three of which Eternatus does not like dealing with. It can also snipe Ho-Oh with Rock Slide, removing one of Eternatus's best checks, and pivot into Eternatus against Water-types such as Alomomola, Arceus-Water, and defensive Primal Kyogre, against which it can begin to set up easily. It should be noted that Choice Specs sets on Eternatus are able to both wallbreak and set up Toxic Spikes for Galarian Darmanitan.
  • Galarian Darmanitan is both weak to Stealth Rock and weakened by Sticky Web, which heavily limits what it is capable of revenge killing against hyper offense teams; this makes Defog users such as Giratina-O and offensive Ho-Oh fantastic partners. They are both good at wearing foes down with Toxic support, and the former is able to check Double Dance Primal Groudon, which Galarian Darmanitan cannot outspeed and revenge kill. Giratina-O is also good at breaking through Tera Water Zygarde, which completely walls Galarian Darmanitan, while also containing Extreme Speed Arceus, which is able to revenge kill Galarian Darmanitan with ease. Mega Diancie is another strong option to pair with Galarian Darmanitan, as it is able to prevent Sticky Web from going up, while Galarian Darmanitan easily removes Pokemon that outspeed and OHKO Mega Diancie such as Zacian-C and Deoxys-A.
  • Galarian Darmanitan also enjoys entry hazard support, which allows it to achieve more damage thresholds such as OHKOing offensive Eternatus with Earthquake. This makes Primal Groudon and Ferrothorn good allies; these two are also able to check Primal Kyogre and Arceus-Water, while Tera Grass Ferrothorn does well against Tera Water Zygarde. Offensive teammates such as Zacian-C, in conjunction with Galarian Darmanitan, can easily wear down their common checks such as Necrozma-DM and Ho-Oh. Zacian-C and offensive Ho-Oh are able to check Calm Mind Arceus-Dark and Arceus-Fairy, both of which are threats to the offense teams Galarian Darmanitan fits best on.

Trapper.description:
• Gothitelle's access to Shadow Tag and Taunt gives it a unique niche in the National Dex Ubers landscape. It lets Gothitelle trap common walls, such as defensive Ho-Oh and Coil Zygarde, forcing them to use Struggle, and it can deny setup from certain sweepers such as Ultra Necrozma. The ability for it to trap many key defensive Pokemon lets it aid offensive threats such as Zacian-C, Calm Mind Arceus-Fairy, and Mega Salamence and lets them forgo coverage for stronger move options. While Gothitelle needs a lot of support from allies, since it cannot trap most offensive Pokemon, its unique toolkit gives it a useful niche on specific bulky offense and balance structures

  • Taunt stops attempts to status, such as Ho-Oh and Primal Groudon's Toxic, from cutting into Gothitelle's longevity. It also blocks phazing attempts such as Primal Groudon's Roar and Ho-Oh's Whirlwind, and it denies attempts to recover health, like Zygarde's Rest.

  • Rest lets Gothitelle stay healthy throughout the trap, decreasing the reliance on Leftovers recovery. It also lets Gothitelle recover from status conditions, like Sacred Fire burns from Ho-Oh and Primal Groudon's Toxic.

  • Charm is Gothitelle's most reliable way to decrease the damage dealt by foes, since most of the Pokemon Gothitelle aims to trap, like Ho-Oh, Zygarde, and Ultra Necrozma, are primarily physical attackers.

  • Cosmic Power is a source of extra physical bulk, boosting Gothitelle's Defense after dropping the foe's attack to -6, and, when fully boosted up, Gothitelle can outheal the foe's damage with Leftovers. Cosmic Power also gives Gothitelle a boost to Special Defense, which can come in handy when trapping defensive Eternatus and Primal Groudon. After forcing a foe to Struggle, very few Pokemon can reliably break through a fully set-up Gothitelle, meaning it can trap foes it normally can't, such as Mega Salamence and Zacian-C.

  • Substitute gives Gothitelle a temporary immunity to the phazing effect of Dragon Tail from Zygarde and Primal Groudon and various status conditions, such as Toxic and Sacred Fire burns from Ho-Oh and Salt Cure from Garganacl. It also blocks Overheat from Primal Groudon and forces it to drop its Special Attack without Gothitelle taking the full-power Overheat. It also keeps Gothitelle safe from critical hits that can deal too much damage for it to comfortably tank. Substitute does have the downside of having less PP than Cosmic Power, which can give Gothitelle trouble when trapping multiple targets in certain matchups, such as against stall or when facing both Rock Tomb Primal Groudon and Brave Bird Ho-Oh, and when forced to run the faster EV spread, since otherwise, it can't outspeed Primal Groudon and block its Overheat.

  • The first EV spread is fully focused on Defense to grant Gothitelle the most consistency when trapping the mainly physical foes, like Zygarde, Ho-Oh, and Ultra Necrozma, giving it an easier time when switching in. The second EV spread invests in enough Speed to outspeed base 90s, like Primal Groudon, Ho-Oh and Zygarde-C. This lets Gothitelle use Charm to lower their Attack before they can use an offensive move, or Gothitelle can use Taunt to block an attempt to status. An alternative set with Choice Scarf, Trick, and enough speed to outpace Yveltal can also be used to bait and trap Yveltal and offensive Eternatus and set up on them with Calm Mind and deal a ton of damage with a boosted Stored Power. This set can struggle when trapping other foes, however, as many Pokemon such as the Calm Mind Arceus formes and Primal Groudon cannot be tricked. It also sacrifices the good matchup it has against Pokemon it usually traps, such as Ho-Oh and Zygarde, as Gothitelle cannot afford to run Charm on Trick variants.

  • Tera Ghost grants Gothitelle an incredible matchup against stall, letting it trap common stall Pokemon Chansey, which only runs Seismic Toss as a damaging move. With the immunity to Seismic Toss, Gothitelle can fully trap Chansey. This, alongside the ability to trap Dondozo and Ho-Oh, means Gothitelle allows both physical and special setup sweepers to break through the stall matchup more easily. It also grants a nice bonus benefit in letting Gothitelle escape trapper Zygarde's Thousand Waves after draining all the PP of its offensive moves in case Gothitelle's trapping is needed at another point in the game. Tera Water gives Gothitelle a resistance to Fire and Steel, letting it trap Overheat Primal Groudon, Dragon Dance Necrozma-DM, and defensive Ho-Oh with higher consistency. It also lets Gothitelle trap Choice-locked Pokemon such as Chien-Pao, Calyrex-I, and Melmetal. Tera Fairy gives Gothitelle an immunity to Dragon Tail phazing from Coil Zygarde, letting it trap it. It also lets Gothitelle trap Chien-Pao locked into Crunch and Choice Scarf Yveltal.

  • Taunt should be used first when facing foes that can give Gothitelle a status condition or phaze it, like defensive Ho-Oh. Charm should be used first when facing a foe that has a high immediate damage output, such as Primal Groudon, or when facing a foe that can boost up, such as Coil Zygarde or Dragon Dance Ultra Necrozma, immediately decreasing their damage output before using Taunt on them to prevent further setup. Charm should also be used when facing a Pokemon that only has offensive moves, such as a Choice item foe like Calyrex-I. If using Rest is needed, using Taunt the turn before Rest is important, as it ensures Gothitelle grants the foe as few turns as possible, being able to use Taunt again right after waking up and only giving one free turn, and when facing a Whirlwind Ho-Oh, this prevents phazing completely.

  • Scouting the moveset of the foe is important when using Gothitelle, since almost all foes that Gothitelle aims to trap have sets that can break through it. Dragon Dance Zygarde has Substitute, which means it doesn't fear Gothitelle's Charm. Primal Groudon and Ho-Oh can also run offensive sets, and Gothitelle does not have the bulk to take their hits comfortably; in Primal Groudon's case, it can OHKO Gothitelle outright with a Heat Crash from its Double Dance set. Rare coverage options can also take Gothitelle by surprise and KO it. Dragon Dance Ultra Necrozma can run Outrage or X-Scissor, which OHKO Gothitelle at +1 after Stealth Rock. Z-Moves also need to be accounted for, as at +1, Arceus-Ground and Necrozma-DM can OHKO Gothitelle with their respective Z-Moves, Tectonic Rage and Searing Sunraze Smash.

  • Playing around critical-hit ranges is crucial when using Gothitelle, as since the PP stall can take a long time, it is likely Gothitelle will take a critical hit at least once. Keeping it at high HP with Rest or consistently maintaining a Substitute, even when the foe is dealing little damage, means Gothitelle has to worry less about fainting to a random critical hit, further boosting its consistency. Foes with a faster Taunt, like Yveltal and Arceus formes, can completely shut down Gothitelle, since it only runs status moves. A Substitute from an opposing Kyurem-B or Zekrom can also block Charm, but Taunt still bypasses their Substitute and can still block their attempts to use a boosting move.

  • Gothitelle pairs incredibly well with strong offensive threats that can take advantage of its ability to trap common defensive checks and counters. Zacian-C and Mega Salamence appreciate Gothitelle trapping Coil Zygarde, defensive Primal Groudon, and Dondozo; Zacian-C also benefits from it trapping Ho-Oh. Calm Mind Arceus formes value Gothitelle trapping Ho-Oh, and Eternatus values it trapping defensive Primal Groudon and both appreciate it trapping Chansey. Gothitelle often only needs to take out one or two of these foes to enable a sweep from one of its allies. These offensive allies can in turn handle the matchups Gothitelle struggles in, like the hyper offense matchup. Zacian-C can reliably come in on Calm Mind Arceus-Dark and -Fairy that counter Gothitelle with a faster Taunt, Mega Salamence can boost its Speed and then punch holes through a usually defensively weak hyper offense team and provides utility with Intimidate, and Calm Mind Arceus formes can aid Gothitelle versus Meteor Beam Eternatus and Chi-Yu. Gothitelle doesn't even need to fully take out one of its foes, as fainting after using Charm once or twice can mean a free turn of setup for an ally to turn into a sweep. For example, at -2, a defensive Primal Groudon deals no meaningful damage to Calm Mind Arceus formes, which means Arceus can get a free Calm Mind off as Primal Groudon is forced out.

  • Preparing for hyper offense is very important, as aside from countering Dragon Dance Ultra Necrozma, Gothitelle is almost useless, since many common hyper offense Pokemon, like Zacian-C and Double Dance Primal Groudon, have too much immediate damage output for Gothitelle to be able to trap or switch into them. Pairing Gothitelle with allies that have a good matchup against hyper offense, like Ditto, Coil Zygarde, and Choice Scarf Yveltal, can help in this matchup. Ditto also has the added bonus of easily being able to scout sets. In turn, Gothitelle helps Coil Zygarde and Choice Scarf Yveltal in the stall matchup.

  • Toxic and Toxic Spikes support from allies like offensive Ho-Oh and Eternatus, respectively, allows Gothitelle to speed up the trapping process, risking less critical hits versus foes like Primal Groudon and saving crucial PP in the stall matchup, since Taunt has limited PP. A badly poisoned foe also means that Gothitelle can trap foes it normally can't, such as support non-Taunt Arceus-Dark, which usually deals too much damage for Gothitelle to reliably trap without fainting, or Dragon Dance Zygarde when running Tera Fairy. Offensive Ho-Oh also has a good matchup against Calm Mind Arceus formes, since Ho-Oh is not reliant on status moves to deal with them. Choice Scarf Yveltal the fastest Defogger in the tier, and it is the most reliable way to clear Sticky Web from the field. This enables Zacian-C and other setup allies to break through hyper offense teams.

Defensive Pivot.description:
• Thanks to its great physical bulk, utility, and excellent typing, Alomomola fills valuable niches on bulkier balance teams. Alomomola is useful as a defensive pivot that can shrug off damage thanks to Regenerator, as a status spreader, and as a Wish passer that increases the longevity of its teammates.
  • Toxic allows Alomomola to cripple the longevity of Ho-Oh, Primal Groudon, and support Arceus formes lacking Refresh. Toxic is especially useful against Primal Groudon and Zygarde, as it keeps Alomomola from being easily set up on while forcing Zygarde to waste Rest PP.
  • Wish allows Alomomola to increase its longevity as well as the longevity of its teammates by providing recovery for allies such as Primal Groudon, Primal Kyogre, Giratina-O, and Specially Offensive Yveltal that have no reliable recovery options. A slow Flip Turn allows Alomomola to safely pass a Wish to the aforementioned Pokemon. Increased longevity allows these teammates to check Zacian-C, Primal Groudon, Arceus, and Marshadow with more efficiency during the game.
  • Protect allows Alomomola to more easily receive a Wish from itself, scout Choice item sets from Marshadow, Yveltal, and Eternatus, and maximize Toxic damage on the foe.
  • Heavy-Duty Boots allows Alomomola to freely pivot without worrying about entry hazards.
  • The first EV spread maximizes Alomomola's mixed bulk, allowing it to shrug off hits from support Arceus formes and Eternatus. The second EV spread maximizes Alomomola's physical bulk, allowing it to survive a +3 Wild Charge from Zacian-C and two uses of Glacial Lance from Choice Band Calyrex-I. Having 0 Speed IVs allows Alomomola to perform a slow Flip Turn against Chansey and Calyrex-I.
  • Tera Dark allows Alomomola to absorb powerful Psychic-type attacks such as Light that Burns the Sky from Ultra Necrozma and Psycho Boost from Deoxys-A. Tera Dark also makes Alomomola one of the few walls capable of handling Deoxys-A thanks to Alomomola's low weight lessening the power of Low Kick. After switching in, Alomomola can immediately threaten to OHKO Deoxys-A with Flip Turn after Stealth Rock and a turn of Life Orb damage.
  • Tera Poison prevents Alomomola from becoming poisoned, allowing it to serve as a switch-in to Toxic Ho-Oh and utility Arceus formes. Tera Poison also allows Alomomola to absorb Toxic Spikes from Eternatus to keep teammates such as Primal Groudon, Primal Kyogre, and support Arceus formes status-free, although switching into Primal Groudon and Arceus-Ground becomes harder.
  • Alomomola is able to swap into any unboosted physical attack besides Bolt Strike from Zekrom throughout the game consistently, since it can use Regenerator to heal itself back up. It can swap in on Mega Salamence or Arceus-Ground and pivot with Flip Turn to safely bring in an answer such as Arceus-Fairy or Arceus-Dark.
  • Thanks to Alomomola's Wish support, teammates without reliable recovery such as Primal Groudon and Giratina-O can switch into Primal Kyogre and Arceus more aggressively throughout the game without worrying about slowly being chipped down.
  • Wallbreaker Primal Kyogre makes it near impossible for Alomomola to safely pass a Wish, so teammates such as Ferrothorn and Primal Groudon are helpful.
  • Alomomola will often get overwhelmed by physical attackers such as Zacian-C, Mega Salamence, and Arceus, so teammates such as Primal Groudon and Arceus-Dark help ease Alomomola's workload.
  • Alomomola provides excellent slow pivoting, so Pokemon that capitalize on a free switch such as Deoxys-A, Choice Band Marshadow, Choice Band Chien-Pao, and Meteor Beam Eternatus make excellent teammates.

Specially Defensive.description:
• Ferrothorn's stellar typing, high bulk, and rare access to Spikes grant it a unique position in the metagame as the cornerstone of hazard-stacking balance teams over Pokemon such as defensive Necrozma-DM. Ferrothorn serves as a sturdy roadblock to wallbreaker Primal Kyogre, which otherwise easily overwhelms most balance teams. Additionally, Ferrothorn checks Ground-types such as Arceus-Ground and Zygarde. However, Ferrothorn struggles against more offensive teams, as Pokemon such as Zacian-C and Mega Salamence are able to take advantage of Ferrothorn's passivity to use it as setup fodder.
  • Power Whip provides Ferrothorn the means to scare out Pokemon such as Primal Kyogre and Arceus-Ground. Wallbreaker Primal Kyogre is OHKOed after Stealth Rock, and defensive Arceus-Ground is 2HKOed after a single layer of Spikes. Ferrothorn is able to capitalize on the switches it forces to set a layer of Spikes or use Leech Seed to help keep itself healthy. Leech Seed also ensures that Ferrothorn can still defeat defensive Primal Kyogre even when burnt and provides some valuable healing for Pokemon such as Primal Groudon and Giratina-O.
  • Knock Off is preferred in the last moveslot, as many of Ferrothorn's common switch-ins, such as Ho-Oh and Yveltal, are heavily dependent on their items to function. Protect is an alternative that enables Ferrothorn to rack up healing from Leftovers and Leech Seed and scout Choice-locked Pokemon such as Rayquaza, Marshadow, and Lunala, but Protect makes it significantly more passive.
  • A Sassy nature and 0 Speed IVs are used to enable Ferrothorn to outspeed Melmetal under Trick Room. This gives Ferrothorn the flexibility to set a layer of Spikes or Knock Off Melmetal's Choice Band, preventing it from being able to 2HKO Ferrothorn with Tera Steel Double Iron Bash. Ferrothorn maximizes its special bulk to better check wallbreaker Primal Kyogre, as even Water Spout fails to 2HKO.
  • Ferrothorn rarely Terastallizes, as it is reliant on its natural typing to function, but it does benefit from Terastallization in some scenarios. Tera Water swaps Ferrothorn's quadruple Fire weakness for a resistance. While Ferrothorn is not able to meaningfully damage any of the Fire-types in the tier, Tera does enable it to beat Ho-Oh if it is the last Pokemon alive, as Ho-Oh seldom runs recovery and is worn down by Iron Barbs and Leech Seed damage before it is able to knock out Ferrothorn. Tera Grass is an alternative to help Ferrothorn better check Arceus-Ground and Zygarde by turning its neutrality to Ground into a resistance. Tera Grass Power Whip is capable of OHKOing Calm Mind Arceus-Ground after a single layer of Spikes and Leech Seed damage. While Ferrothorn cannot beat Coil Zygarde directly even with Tera Grass, its newfound Ground resistance provides it with extra turns to use Knock Off or Leech Seed before switching to a teammate that can handle Zygarde. Ferrothorn does still have some issues with Dragon Dance Zygarde, however, as it commonly runs Substitute.
  • Ferrothorn is best used in the early- and mid-game to set Spikes against defensive Pokemon such as utility Arceus formes and Alomomola. If Primal Kyogre is on the opposing team, Ferrothorn should prioritize preserving HP until the set is revealed, as it can easily get chipped to where it is unable to switch into wallbreaker Primal Kyogre's Water Spout. Ferrothorn can be used as a lead against hyper offense teams due to its immunity to Smeargle's Spore and Glimmora's Mortal Spin enabling it to break their Focus Sashes easily. Ferrothorn matches up poorly into most hyper offense teams due to its overall passivity, so sacrificing Ferrothorn to deal with suicide leads enables teammates such as Primal Groudon and Arceus-Dark to preserve HP and better handle common threats such as Zacian-C and Ultra Necrozma.
  • Ferrothorn shines against balance and stall teams, as the passive damage it deals racks up over the course of longer games. Many defensive Pokemon are unable to meaningfully damage Ferrothorn, which makes it difficult to wear down. Stall teams in particular have a tough time preventing Ferrothorn from making progress; the only Knock Off absorber, Arceus-Dark, is unable to meaningfully hurt Ferrothorn, as Foul Play activates Iron Barbs. This allows Ferrothorn to keep both itself and its teammates healthy with Leech Seed while freely laying down Spikes.
  • Ferrothorn pairs best with defensive Pokemon that are vulnerable to wallbreaker Primal Kyogre. As such, Zygarde is an excellent teammate for Ferrothorn due to it countering the tier's prominent Fire-types, Primal Groudon and Ho-Oh. Zygarde is also the best blanket physical wall in the tier and is able to help check physical attackers such as Marshadow and Mega Salamence that are able to break Ferrothorn. Defensive Primal Groudon is also an excellent teammate for Ferrothorn, as it can set Stealth Rock and work in conjunction with Ferrothorn to ensure that Primal Kyogre rarely poses a threat. Ferrothorn can check wallbreaker Primal Kyogre, which often overwhelms Primal Groudon and leaves it unable to check Pokemon such as Zacian-C, while Primal Groudon can remove Pokemon such as Ho-Oh and Eternatus that that threaten Ferrothorn.
  • Ferrothorn struggles against Taunt users such as Yveltal and utility Arceus formes. Consequently, Arceus-Fairy is a solid teammate for Ferrothorn, as it counters specially offensive Yveltal and can use Taunt to prevent Ho-Oh, Yveltal, and Giratina-O from removing Ferrothorn's Spikes.
  • Choice Band Marshadow is a decent offensive partner for Ferrothorn due to its ability to revenge kill many Pokemon found on hyper offense teams, including Ultra Necrozma, Deoxys-A, and Zacian-C. Ditto can also fill this role, as it threatens to reverse sweep by copying Pokemon such as Zacian-C and Mega Salamence.

Setup Sweeper.description:
• Being the sole Electric-type of the tier, Zekrom can remove defensive Pokemon such as Ho-Oh, Primal Kyogre, Arceus-Water, and Yveltal. Zekrom's ability, Teravolt, also allows it to break through Dondozo, making it a strong wallbreaker for hyper offense structures.
  • Outrage, when paired with Dragonium Z, becomes a powerful nuke option for Zekrom to use against Pokemon like Primal Groudon, Arceus-Ground, Giratina-O, and Eternatus, all of which resist or are immune to Bolt Strike.
  • Substitute eases predictions, as Zekrom commonly forces switches, and it blocks status moves such as Will-O-Wisp from Giratina-O and Toxic from support Arceus formes. It also helps Zekrom set up more easily against Pokemon like Ho-Oh, which attempts to burn Zekrom with Sacred Fire. Roost can be used to give Zekrom more longevity throughout a match and as it sets up.
  • The given EVs allow Zekrom to always outspeed Deoxys-A after a boost while ensuring it survives uninvested Judgment from Arceus-Fairy and two Earth Powers from utility Arceus formes. Alternatively, the second EV spread allows Zekrom to OHKO Ho-Oh, Mega Mewtwo Y, and Primal Kyogre without any boosts, 2HKO defensive Necrozma-DM and Extreme Killer Arceus, and OHKO Zacian-C and Dondozo at +1. The Adamant nature also gives Zekrom better chances to OHKO Primal Groudon with +1 Devastating Drake after Stealth Rock while always outspeeding Necrozma-DM, but it cannot outspeed Zacian-C after a boost.
  • Zekrom's unique typing allows it to take hits from Mega Salamence, Primal Kyogre, and Necrozma-DM's STAB moves; however, its exploitable weaknesses and lack of ability to serve as a wall make this trait only useful in a pinch, as Zekrom shouldn't be taking many hits if it wants to sweep effectively. In the scenario where Zekrom struggles to set up, unboosted Devastating Drake is a solid option for weakening foes such as Primal Kyogre, Primal Groudon and Giratina-O to let Zekrom's teammates handle them more easily.
  • Primal Kyogre makes a great partner to Zekrom with its ability to check Primal Groudon, wearing it down for Zekrom to clean up with its Z-Move afterwards. Offensive Necrozma-DM breaks through Fairy-types like Arceus-Fairy and Zacian-C for Zekrom to more comfortably use Devastating Drake while also allowing Zekrom to use Outrage once said Fairy-types aren't a factor.
  • Strong physical attackers like Marshadow and Arceus appreciate Zekrom's ability to break through Dondozo, Giratina, and Primal Groudon. Strong special attackers like Calm Mind Arceus formes, Primal Kyogre, and Eternatus also appreciate Zekrom breaking through special walls like Ho-Oh and Chansey, while they can help wear down physical walls like Primal Groudon and Arceus-Ground so Zekrom can break through them more easily with Dragonium Z.
  • Suicide leads like Shuckle and Smeargle can set up Sticky Web for Zekrom, assisting the secondary EV spread with its drop in Speed while also setting additional entry hazards to meet important damage thresholds; in return, Zekrom offensively pressures Ho-Oh and Yveltal and dissuades them from using Defog to remove Sticky Web.

Defensive Pivot.description:
• Landorus-T is a useful pivot for offense and balance teams that is able to check threats such as Primal Groudon and physical Arceus-Ground with Intimidate. Its good Attack stat keeps it from being passive and threatens Pokemon such as Zacian-C, Primal Groudon, and Zekrom, which allows it to have a niche over Alomomola as a physical pivot. Its limited longevity means its window to serve as a pivot is smaller though. It is also unable to recover from specially offensive hits such as Overheat Primal Groudon and Judgement from Arceus formes like Alomomola can due to its lack of recovery.

  • Earthquake takes advantage of Landorus-T's high Attack stat and deals super effective damage to threats like Primal Groudon, Zacian-C, and Eternatus while hitting a large portion of the tier neutrally.

  • Landorus-T can provide useful utility with Stealth Rock, which aids Pokemon such as Chien-Pao and Marshadow in wallbreaking. Toxic can be used to wear down Pokemon Landorus-T cannot otherwise threaten such as Zygarde and support Arceus formes. It can also be used to punish Defoggers such as Ho-Oh and Giratina-O.

  • Taunt prevents Necrozma-DM from setting up against Landorus-T, Ferrothorn from freely setting Spikes, and Primal Groudon from using Toxic. In addition, it stops Ho-Oh from using Defog.

  • Rocky Helmet allows Landorus-T to punish contact moves from threats it checks such as Zacian-C, Marshadow, and Extreme Killer Arceus.

  • The given EV spread avoids a 2HKO from Choice Band Marshadow's Poltergeist after Stealth Rock while also outspeeding uninvested Zygarde, with the Attack investment ensuring that Earthquake OHKOs Zacian-C after Rocky Helmet damage.

  • Landorus-T does not usually need to Terastallize, as its base typing is excellent for the job it needs to do. In addition, teammates such as Chien-Pao, Marshadow, and Rayquaza need it to wallbreak. However, Tera Water can be used in order to take on Glacial Lance from Calyrex-I more easily while tanking Heat Crash from Double Dance Primal Groudon and Behemoth Blade from Zacian-C in a pinch.

  • Tera Dark can be used to allow Landorus-T to serve as a switch-in to the large amount of Psychic-types in the tier such as Ultra Necrozma and Deoxys-A, though Deoxys-A can still 2HKO with Low Kick. In addition, it provides a niche but useful immunity to Taunt from Prankster Grimmsnarl, allowing Landorus-T to serve as a slow pivot against it.

  • Landorus-T is usually best used early-game, where it can set Stealth Rock, allowing allies such as Chien-Pao, Rayquaza, Primal Kyogre, and Marshadow to wallbreak more efficiently. Thanks to Intimidate, Landorus-T can force early-game switches from defensive Primal Groudon, though it relies on its great typing to serve as a pivot due to its relative frailty. Landorus-T's main job early-game is to safely pivot in strong wallbreakers such as Chien-Pao and Marshadow on offensive teams so they can heavily dent the opposing team quickly.

  • Landorus-T can also be used as a one-time check to dangerous threats such as Zacian-C and Primal Groudon. Its limited longevity means it cannot check these threats long-term. Sometimes, the best move can be to sacrifice Landorus-T to their attacks, as its Intimidate alone can force out these threats the next turn in addition to providing Rocky Helmet chip damage or provide a teammate with an excellent setup or revenge killing opportunity.

  • Landorus-T is not extremely weak to entry hazards. However, Stealth Rock can be a nuisance to it, as it cuts down on its already limited longevity. Therefore, Defoggers such as Giratina-O and Ho-Oh make excellent teammates. This increases Landorus-T's longevity as well as the longevity of Pokemon it pivots in like Chien-Pao. These two can also aid in checking Primal Groudon and Zacian-C, which Landorus-T cannot do long-term. Alomomola also mitigates Landorus-T's longevity issues by being a Wish passer that lessens its burden at checking physical attackers.

  • Landorus-T is extremely vulnerable to special attackers such as Yveltal and Palkia-O, so checks to these threats such as Fezandipiti, Calm Mind Arceus-Dark and Arceus-Fairy are appreciated.

Dragon Dance.description:
• Kyurem-B serves as a fearsome physical sweeper, using its monstrous Attack stat to tear apart weakened teams. Kyurem-B is typically used as a late-game wincon on offense teams after its would-be checks such as Primal Groudon, Necrozma-DM, and Ho-Oh lose the ability to check it. Kyurem-B can also be used mid-game to break through balance teams due to the difficulty other teams have switching in. Kyurem-B often forces the other team to use their Terastallization to check it. Kyurem-B typically fits best on offense teams, especially hyper offense teams. However, Kyurem-B's downsides can make it difficult to justify on a team, as it often relies on Terastallization to perform its sweep, it competes with other setup sweepers such as Necrozma-DM and Mega Salamence, and it's weak to Stealth Rock.
  • Icicle Spear is Kyurem-B's best Ice-type STAB move, serving as consistent high damage output using Loaded Dice. Icicle Spear is a spammable STAB move due to the tier's abundance of Dragon- and Ground-type Pokemon. At +1 with a Jolly nature, Icicle Spear gets guaranteed 2HKOs on Ho-Oh and offensive Primal Groudon with a chance to 2HKO utility Arceus formes. With an Adamant nature, Icicle Spear can guarantee the 2HKO on utility Arceus formes and become very likely to 2HKO defensive Primal Groudon.
  • Fusion Bolt lets Kyurem-B hit all of the targets that resist Icicle Spear for at least neutral damage. Fusion Bolt 2HKOes defensive Primal Kyogre without needing to use Dragon Dance first. In addition, at +1, Kyurem-B has a chance to OHKO defensive Primal Kyogre and defensive Ho-Oh, and it can beat Dondozo or force it to Terastallize. Fusion Bolt is also Kyurem-B's best coverage move against Necrozma-DM.
  • Substitute lets Kyurem-B dodge status conditions, particularly Toxic from Pokemon such as Alomomola and Primal Groudon, which may threaten to stop its sweep, while also making switching to handle Kyurem-B risky. Kyurem-B's Substitute can survive weaker hits as well such as Giratina-O's Shadow Sneak. In addition, Substitute lets Kyurem-B bypass Trick and Charm from Gothitelle and Imposter from Ditto.
  • Scale Shot can be used as a secondary STAB option, since it is a useful midground option, as defensive cores that combine to resist Icicle Spear and Fusion Bolt will often be hit neutrally by Scale Shot such as a core of Zygarde and Primal Kyogre, allowing you to get around needing to predict defensively. The Speed boost given by Scale Shot may also come in handy, as it allows Kyurem-B to boost past a faster Pokemon while still getting damage such as an opposing Deoxys-A in the back that would threaten to revenge kill it at +1.
  • Tera Electric bolsters the power of Fusion Bolt while also turning incoming Steel-type attacks from a weakness into a resistance. This is incredibly useful in the Necrozma-DM matchup, as Fusion Bolt can 2HKO defensive Necrozma-DM, while Sunsteel Strike from defensive Necrozma-DM can 4HKO Kyurem-B after Stealth Rock, which notably doesn't break Kyurem-B's Substitute. In addition, Tera Electric gives Kyurem-B a favorable roll to OHKO Zacian-C if one layer of Spikes is up.
  • Tera Fairy is a defensive Terastallization option, most notably flipping Dragon-type moves such as Eternatus's Dynamax Cannon from a weakness into an immunity while also turning Fighting-type moves from a weakness into a resistance such as Marshadow's Low Kick.
  • Tera Ground + Tera Blast in the third moveslot hits the Steel-types that Kyurem-B normally struggles to break through, most notably Necrozma-DM, while also letting it threaten Terastallized Giratina-O, as Teravolt lets it ignore Levitate.
  • An EV spread of 40 HP / 252 Atk / 216 Spe with an Adamant nature lets Kyurem-B outspeed Adamant nature Zekrom and other neutral Speed nature Pokemon with a base 90 Speed. In addition, the bulk investment allows Kyurem-B to avoid an OHKO from Stone Edge from physical setup sweeper Arceus-Ground at +1.
  • The 252 Atk / 92 Def / 164 Spe EV spread with a Jolly nature allows Kyurem-B to outspeed Deoxys-A after a Dragon Dance while avoiding an OHKO from +2 Tera Normal Arceus's Extreme Speed and Ultra Necrozma's Stone Edge.
  • Kyurem-B is best used as a mid- or late-game sweeper. While Kyurem-B has usable bulk, enough to take a hit, its Stealth Rock weakness limits its ability to come onto the field, so it is fairly committal to send in. As such, reserve Kyurem-B for when you feel comfortable bringing it in such as in the face of a Pokemon it can hit super effectively.
  • Kyurem-B is also a fearsome wallbreaker, which gives it an important niche versus balance and stall teams. Kyurem-B can punish passive play by using Substitute against defensive Pokemon, which allows it to set up much more safely. Kyurem-B also has good matchups against keystone defensive Pokemon such as defensive Eternatus and Dondozo. Kyurem-B has to be careful about foes using defensive Terastallization to play around it and threaten it back.
  • Kyurem-B wants to use Terastallization often, so you should support Kyurem-B with Pokemon that don't rely on Terastallization such as Primal Groudon and Primal Kyogre. Kyurem-B also can force the other team to expend their Terastallization to beat it, removing some prediction for its teammates. Ho-Oh makes a great partner on bulkier offense teams, as it doesn't need to Terastallize that often, and it provides Defog support to remove Stealth Rock for Kyurem-B to come in more easily.
  • Sticky Web support from Smeargle or Shuckle is also great for Kyurem-B, as that allows it to leverage its passable but flawed Speed tier much better.
  • Kyurem-B struggles to break through Steel-types such as Necrozma-DM and Zacian-C, so one should pair Kyurem-B with attackers that can deal with them such as Primal Groudon, Ho-Oh, and Arceus-Ground.

Specially Offensive.description:
• Yveltal's amazing STAB combination, which is only resisted by Zacian-C and niche Pokemon like Mega Diancie, in conjunction with Life Orb makes it a potent wallbreaker and stallbreaker for balance, bulky offense, and hyper offense teams alike. This is to the point where it is deemed mandatory on Sticky Web teams due to its efficiency and role compression as a source of priority and strong damage dealer as well as its sheer versatility with its movepool and Terastallization options.

  • Yveltal's Speed tier outside of Sticky Web is also fantastic, outspeeding the majority of the defensive metagame including Pokemon such as Primal Groudon, Zygarde, and Ho-Oh and only being outsped by Calm Mind Arceus formes and Eternatus.

  • It also carries useful defensive traits against Pokemon such as Ultra Necrozma, Deoxys-A, and Marshadow, despite it being weak to Stealth Rock. This makes it more flexible compared to other wallbreakers like Rayquaza and the aforementioned Deoxys-A, which rely much more on pivot support and revenge killing opportunities; this is all while simultaneously being good against opposing offense teams and not being prediction reliant.

  • Oblivion Wing provides Yveltal with a source of longevity, making up for its Stealth Rock weakness and the Life Orb recoil it takes while being useful against foes such as Marshadow, Alomomola, Arceus-Fairy, and Arceus-Dark, with Oblivion Wing being needed to beat the latter two under Sticky Web.

  • Taunt is mandatory on Yveltal, since it allows it to make progress much more easily by punishing more passive Pokemon such as Coil Zygarde, Ferrothorn, and Alomomola. This lets it avoid status conditions such as paralysis and Toxic poison while preventing any setup opportunities from Zygarde, Necrozma-DM, Arceus-Ground, and Zacian-C. It also ensures that entry hazards such as Sticky Web stay up against common Defog users such as defensive Ho-Oh and Giratina-O, especially with Tera Fire for the former to resist Sacred Fire.

  • Sucker Punch allows Yveltal to revenge kill Ultra Necrozma after a single layer of Spikes, Deoxys-A, and Mega Mewtwo Y, making Yveltal good at handling opposing offense teams.

  • Knock Off allows for better wallbreaking against balance and stall teams, notably removing Heavy-Duty Boots from Ho-Oh and opposing defensive Yveltal alongside removing Eviolite from Chansey, all of which Yveltal's teammates can take advantage of.

  • Heat Wave should only be used with Tera Fire and on Sticky Web teams, but it allows Yveltal to snipe Zacian-C, removing one of Yveltal's sturdy checks, but it is significantly less useful than the other two options otherwise.

  • A Naive nature is preferred over Hasty on the first EV spread, since it allows Yveltal to withstand pressure from Marshadow more reliably. It also allows Yveltal to avoid an OHKO from Deoxys-A's Rock Slide even after Stealth Rock chip damage.

  • The secondary EV spread allows Yveltal to avoid several OHKO rolls including Choice Band Rayquaza's Dragon Ascent, Zacian-C's Wild Charge, and Choice Specs Lunala's Moonblast; uninvested Arceus-Fairy's Judgment and defensive Primal Groudon's Overheat after one round of Life Orb recoil; and defensive Primal Kyogre's Ice Beam after Stealth Rock chip damage and one round of Life Orb recoil. This is all while still outspeeding base-95 Speed Pokemon such as Rayquaza and Kyurem-B with a Timid nature, at the cost of not outspeeding Lunala anymore. A Modest nature is not encouraged since outspeeding Rayquaza on Sticky Web teams, as well as maximum Speed Primal Groudon and Primal Kyogre, Kyurem-B, and Zekrom outside of Sticky Web, is heavily important for Yveltal's effectiveness as a wallbreaker.

  • Tera Dark is the primary Tera type on Yveltal, bringing its damage to all new heights. It notably lets Yveltal OHKO Eruption Primal Groudon and Rayquaza and 2HKO defensive Primal Kyogre and Ho-Oh, all with Dark Pulse. It also lets Yveltal more reliably OHKO Ultra Necrozma with Sucker Punch, which is necessary for the second EV spread, as it runs a Timid nature. Tera Dark also removes Yveltal's weakness to Stealth Rock, giving it more longevity despite struggling slightly more against Marshadow, since it no longer takes neutral damage from Low Kick.

  • Tera Flying boosts the power of Oblivion Wing, letting Yveltal 2HKO Arceus-Fairy after Stealth Rock and defensive Yveltal as well as have a small chance to 2HKO Calm Mind Arceus-Dark after Stealth Rock, thus allowing it to muscle through these Arceus formes under Sticky Web. Removing the Dark-type from Yveltal is especially useful to punish Arceus-Fairy harder, although Yveltal no longer resists Ghost-type attacks from Marshadow and Lunala.

  • Tera Fire lets Heat Wave OHKO Zacian-C while letting Yveltal more safely deal with defensive Ho-Oh and the aforementioned Arceus-Fairy. This arguably makes Tera Fire the best Terastallization option for Sticky Web teams, since Yveltal is strong enough without Tera Dark, although it does not let Yveltal quickly muscle through Arceus-Fairy like Tera Flying does. Tera Fire must only be used on Sticky Web teams, however, since that's the only situation where Heat Wave is useful, and beating Ho-Oh and Arceus-Fairy is only worth exhausting Terastallization for when Yveltal is encouraged to use Taunt to maintain Sticky Web against the former and it is able to outspeed and use Taunt against the latter to win the one-on-one.

  • It is ideal to avoid status conditions as much as possible, especially since Yveltal has poor longevity. Toxic from Eternatus and defensive Arceus-Dark reduces Yveltal's longevity drastically, while Oblivion Wing struggles to make up for it. Paralysis from Zygarde and Giratina-O means Yveltal cannot outspeed bulky targets anymore, notably Primal Groudon, Ho-Oh, and Zygarde. Burns from Ho-Oh and Giratina-O drastically weaken Sucker Punch, notably preventing it from OHKOing Mega Mewtwo Y and Ultra Necrozma, even with Tera Dark, although this weakness is heavily mitigated for Tera Fire variants.

  • Outside of hyper offense teams, Yveltal works best early-to-mid game, where it is able to break through physically defensive walls such as Primal Groudon and Zygarde for its teammates. While it appreciates pivot support from Pokemon such as Alomomola and Landorus-T, Yveltal can be used aggressively against moves it is immune to, such as Primal Groudon's Precipice Blades and Lunala's Psyshock; this is extremely risky, however, and it is not ideal to do this frequently since Yveltal is easy to KO with Overheat from Primal Groudon or Moonblast from Lunala, with both OHKOing after one round of Life Orb damage.

  • On Sticky Web teams, wallbreaking is Yveltal's main purpose, and so it should be used early-game to break through physically defensive walls such as Primal Groudon and Zygarde while maintaining Sticky Web and other hazards against Defog users such as Giratina-O and Ho-Oh with Taunt.

  • Against teams with Ultra Necrozma, Deoxys-A, and Mega Mewtwo Y, it is necessary to preserve Sucker Punch Yveltal in order to revenge kill these threats and prevent them from getting out of hand. If Yveltal is running Knock Off instead, not only is it important to run another form of priority, such as Marshadow's Shadow Sneak, but Yveltal may want to play more aggressively with double switches to stop these threats from setting up safely as well as to wallbreak harder against defensive cores including Ho-Oh, Eternatus, and Zygarde.

  • Yveltal is walled by Calm Mind Arceus-Dark, Arceus-Fairy, defensive Eternatus, and Fezandipiti. On hyper offense and bulky offense teams, Behemoth Blade Zacian-C handles all four of these and checks Extreme Killer Arceus, which would otherwise easily revenge kill Yveltal after Life Orb chip damage. Zacian-C appreciates Yveltal breaking through Primal Groudon and Dondozo for it in return.

  • Sticky Web support from Smeargle or Shuckle helps Yveltal prevent Calm Mind Arceus-Dark from setting up on it, letting Yveltal beat it and even Arceus-Fairy as well with Tera Flying or Fire one-on-one. Smeargle also removes Stealth Rock with Mortal Spin or Rapid Spin, assisting in Yveltal's longevity.

  • Meteor Beam Eternatus is able to break past Arceus-Fairy and opposing Eternatus and snipe Ho-Oh with Meteor Beam while appreciating Yveltal breaking through Necrozma-DM. Finally, Chi-Yu can help overwhelm common checks with Yveltal, such as Arceus-Fairy and Eternatus; it too has Taunt to maintain Sticky Web.

  • On bulky offense and balance teams, Primal Groudon is a great partner, since it appreciates Yveltal breaking past Zygarde and Giratina-O for it and Primal Groudon can check Arceus-Fairy, Zacian-C, and defensive Primal Kyogre while supporting Yveltal with entry hazards. Offensive Ho-Oh is a similar case, checking Arceus-Fairy and Arceus-Dark, and it helps deal with Yveltal's weakness to Stealth Rock with Defog support while potentially weakening foes such as Eternatus with Thunder Wave for Yveltal to punish later.

  • Dragon Dance Necrozma-DM and Dragon Dance Zygarde appreciate Yveltal breaking through common defensive walls such as Primal Groudon, Coil Zygarde, and Giratina-O for their late-game sweeps, while Coil Zygarde is useful for paralysis support and as a blanket check to physical threats such as Primal Groudon and offensive Ho-Oh that may want to trade with Yveltal.

Defensive.description:
• With a great defensive typing, respectable bulk, and STAB Foul Play boosted by its ability, Yveltal makes for an excellent defensive wall. Yveltal's immunity to Psychic allows it to check threats such as Deoxys-A, Ultra Necrozma, and Mega Mewtwo Y.

  • Foul Play often forces switches due to its power and deals large amounts of damage to threats such as Extreme Killer Arceus, Primal Groudon, Mega Salamence, Arceus-Ground, and Ultra Necrozma. This also prevents them, as well as Zacian-C, from setting up without massive punishment.

  • Toxic allows Yveltal to chip down Pokemon that resist or have the bulk to tank Foul Play, such as Zygarde, Primal Kyogre, Arceus-Dark, Arceus-Water, and Ho-Oh. U-turn can be used instead, allowing Yveltal to grab momentum against predicted switch-ins such as Arceus-Dark and Ho-Oh while bringing in wallbreakers such as Zacian-C and Primal Kyogre.

  • Taunt prevents Primal Kyogre, Necrozma-DM, and Zygarde from setting up on Yveltal. Additionally, it prevents Arceus-Dark, Arceus-Water, and Ho-Oh from crippling Yveltal with Toxic or Will-O-Wisp while also preventing them from using Refresh and Recover, reducing their longevity.

  • The given EV spread allows Yveltal to outspeed the different support Arceus formes, meaning it can use Taunt to block their Taunt or utility moves. With this, Yveltal also outspeeds Primal Groudon and Primal Kyogre, allowing it to cripple them with Toxic or prevent setup with Taunt.

  • Tera Ghost allows Yveltal to block Extreme Speed from Arceus and Low Kick from Marshadow at the cost of losing the ability to absorb Psychic-type attacks from Ultra Necrozma and Mega Mewtwo Y.

  • Tera Poison allows Yveltal to better check Zacian-C and wall Arceus-Fairy with the help of Taunt, though checking Primal Groudon and Ultra Necrozma becomes significantly harder.

  • Defensive Yveltal is a great fit on teams looking for Pokemon that can check a large variety of physical threats and threaten them out consistently, such as balance and stall teams.

  • Throughout the game, Yveltal should try to look for opportunities to spread Toxic to the opposing team or provide momentum through U-turn. Yveltal can create these opportunities by threatening out various physical attackers such as Arceus, Necrozma-DM, and Mega Salamence with Foul Play, forcing opponents to make unfavorable moves.

  • Yveltal should be able to safely stay in on most support Arceus formes thanks to Taunt, as well as against Giratina-O and Zygarde.

  • Yveltal can often get overwhelmed by threats such as Zacian-C and Arceus-Fairy, so a teammate such as Ho-Oh or Necrozma-DM that can wall these Pokemon greatly helps it.

  • Fast sweepers such as Zacian-C, Extreme Killer Arceus, and Mega Salamence that take advantage of the chip damage Yveltal provides also make great teammates.

Choice Scarf.description:
• Foul Play makes Yveltal an excellent revenge killer against many offensive teams, being able to use the Attack boosts of Pokemon such as Swords Dance Arceus formes, Primal Groudon, and Necrozma-DM against them to break right through them before they have the chance to cause major damage. Dark Pulse is a strong Dark-type STAB move if a more consistent damage output is required to clean late-game.

  • Oblivion Wing allows Yveltal to reliably revenge kill Marshadow and maintain its health somewhat. Roost may be considered to keep itself healthy as well, but locking into it can be risky against many teams.

  • Defog allows Yveltal to be one of the best solutions to hyper offense teams in the tier, clearing entry hazards early-game due to how many switches it forces with Foul Play. Yveltal notably does not have its Speed dropped by Sticky Web. If its team already has a consistent Defogger, Toxic may be chosen to punish support Arceus formes more consistently.

  • U-turn allows Yveltal to better take advantage of Pokemon that switch in like defensive Eternatus, Arceus-Dark, and Arceus-Fairy to maintain momentum for its team.

  • The given EV spread allows Yveltal to outspeed fully invested base 95s such as Rayquaza and Kyurem-B and survive a +1 Outrage from Dragon Dance Ultra Necrozma, and revenge kill it with either Foul Play or Dark Pulse. The rest of the EVs are dumped into Special Attack to strengthen Oblivion Wing.

  • Tera Dark allows Yveltal to OHKO +3 Zacian-C with Foul Play and removes its Stealth Rock weakness; however, Tera Steel is also a good option to allow Yveltal to become much more resilient against the likes of Extreme Killer Arceus while also turning its Stealth Rock and Fairy-type weaknesses into resistances.

  • Because Yveltal is still quite physically bulky and is able to punish foes even if they boost, it is best to use Yveltal proactively rather than reactively to keep setup sweepers in check by bringing it in on predicted setup moves or to take a hit and fire back with Foul Play.

  • Yveltal fits very well on offensive teams where its short-term utility and late-game cleaning prowess are put on full display, being able to almost singlehandedly shut down entire hyper offense teams that such structures otherwise have trouble against and trade blows with surprise sweepers that may otherwise run away with the game.

  • Alternative Defoggers like Ho-Oh and Giratina-O are great teammates on such teams, matching up very well against the tier's best Stealth Rock setters and keeping hazards off for Yveltal to stay as healthy as possible throughout a game.

  • Offensive Necrozma-DM and Primal Groudon variants are also notable partners, being able to take advantage of the many switches Yveltal forces and the common Fairy-types it will find itself luring in for a safe setup opportunity. This allows Yveltal to clean up later. Furthermore, they are capable of setting up Stealth Rock in order to further facilitate Yveltal late-game, as Yveltal greatly appreciates the prior damage on Pokemon such as support Arceus formes and Eternatus to more easily clean up games.

Coil.description:
• Coil Zygarde is a nigh irreplaceable staple on balance and bulky offense teams due to blanket checking the vast majority of the metagame's physical attackers while providing disruption and a bulky wincon against a variety of structures. Zygarde’s unparalleled bulk enables it to counter some of the scariest wallbreakers in Choice Band Marshadow and Swords Dance Primal Groudon. Furthermore, Zygarde’s immaculate synergy with Terastallization allows it to extend its defensive reach to wall Pokémon such as Zacian-C and Dragon Dance Necrozma-DM. Due to its immense defensive role compression and consistency, Zygarde can support a dazzling variety of Pokémon. Consequently, every balance and bulky offense team should consider Zygarde at some point in the teambuilding process, while every team needs to be able to contain it.

  • Thousand Arrows's ability to damage Flying-types enables Zygarde to forgo the need for additional attacking moves and delve into its utility movepool to best support its team. Furthermore, the dearth of Grass- and Bug-types in National Dex Ubers means that Thousand Arrows hits nearly every relevant Pokemon for neutral damage.

  • Glare is immensely spammable and provides team support in addition to facilitating Zygarde itself to sweep late-game once its checks have been appropriately chipped. If Zygarde is using Glare, slower teammates such as Primal Groudon and Ho-Oh should consider some minor Speed investment to outspeed paralyzed foes such as Eternatus and Zacian-C. Dragon Tail provides Zygarde the means to phaze Pokemon that may set up on it such as the Arceus formes due to bypassing Taunt or prevent a trap from non-Tera Fairy Gothitelle. Toxic is an additional option that annoys opposing Coil Zygarde and Ho-Oh while helping slightly against stall. However, forgoing the utility of Dragon Tail or Glare enables Pokemon such as Swords Dance Primal Groudon, Dragon Dance Necrozma-DM, and Zacian-C to easily set up on and muscle past Zygarde.

  • Zygarde's immense bulk, especially after transformation, enables it to utilize Rest and stay healthy throughout the course of a game, enabling it to be a serviceable status absorber. This is further facilitated by free turns granted by Glare. However, Zygarde is quite vulnerable while asleep and can provide opportunities for Pokemon such as Taunt Calm Mind Arceus formes and Primal Kyogre to enter safely.

  • The full physical bulk investment in the first EV spread is required to enable Zygarde to serve as a blanket physical wall, as it otherwise crumples against physical attackers such as Swords Dance Primal Groudon and boosted Zacian-C. The second EV spread enables Zygarde to more effectively take on special attackers aiming to exploit its lower Special Defense such as Eruption Primal Groudon and defensive Primal Kyogre while outspeeding paralyzed Zacian-C after transformation and being able to survive Tera Dragon Eternatus's +1 Dynamax Cannon after Terastallization . Although Zygarde is still an excellent physical wall and Marshadow counter, it is significantly more vulnerable to the most powerful physical attacks such as Zacian-C's +3 Behemoth Blade and Double Dance Primal Groudon's +2 Precipice Blades.

  • Zygarde is perhaps the Pokemon that is most synergistic with Terastallization due to its ability to flip Zygarde's exploitable Ice-, Dragon-, and Fairy-type weaknesses. It often uses Terastallization to soak an attack and paralyze or phaze boosted Pokemon that would otherwise threaten it such as Dragon Dance Necrozma-DM and Play Rough Zacian-C. Tera Fairy and Water each have their merits, as they enable Zygarde to handle specific threats and should not be used interchangably.

  • Tera Water is Zygarde's most generally useful option. Despite the Electric-type weakness Zygarde is able to stomach Zacian-C's +3 Wild Charge, while Zygarde's obscene bulk enables it to continue being an immovable physical wall despite a lack of notable resistances. However, maintaining a resistance to Primal Groudon's Overheat and resisting Necrozma-DM's +1 Searing Sunraze Smash, which would otherwise OHKO Zygarde, is appreciated.

  • Tera Fairy is also an option that should be considered. Despite Tera Fairy introducing weaknesses to Zacian-C's Behemoth Blade, Dragon Dance Necrozma-DM's Sunsteel Strike, and Eternatus's Sludge Bomb, it is still extremely good. Dragon Dance Zygarde is immensely threatening to the bulky offense and balance structures Coil Zygarde anchors and is able to use Tera Water Zygarde as setup fodder. Tera Fairy Zygarde is one of the few options for defensive counterplay available to these structures while also being able to turn the tables and use Dragon Dance Zygarde to facilitate its own setup. Tera Fairy also helps Zygarde defensively against Calm Mind Arceus-Dark and physical Giratina-O, preventing the latter from phazing Zygarde with Dragon Tail.

  • Coil Zygarde is an integral part of the defensive backbone of most bulky offense and balance teams and finds switch-in opportunities on Pokemon such as Primal Groudon and Marshadow.
