However, Zygarde's special bulk is middling, and it should be used cautiously against special attackers such as Primal Kyogre, Lunala, and Eternatus even if it is able to survive a hit, as relying on Rest leaves it quite vulnerable. Additionally, due to Zygarde's low Speed and reliance on status moves, it struggles with Taunt users such as Yveltal and the Arceus formes. Calm Mind Arceus formes especially often use Zygarde as setup fodder. As Zygarde lacks offensive investment, its Thousand Arrows is quite weak and struggles to threaten most Pokemon for meaningful damage until it has accumulated multiple Coil boosts.

  • Against hyper offense teams Zygarde should focus on attempting to check or trade with a single Pokemon such as Extreme Killer Arceus, Primal Groudon, or Zacian-C, as it will rarely be given enough turns to become offensively threatening. Additionally, Zygarde is entirely deadweight against stall teams, as it is completely walled by Dondozo, but it can still provide value as a status sponge, pivot, and cleaner once Dondozo has been removed. Although Zygarde cannot make meaningful progress against stall teams, it is not threatened by stall in return with the exception of Eternatus's Dynamax Cannon which 2HKOes it.

  • While Zygarde may be a blanket physical wall, it is not impenetrable. Notably, Ultra Necrozma's +1 Light That Burns the Sky is capable of OHKOingZygarde. Consequently, Zygarde requires teammates that are capable of offensively or defensively checking Ultra Necrozma such as Calm Mind Arceus-Dark, Marshadow, and Yveltal. Defensive Arceus-Dark should not be used with Coil Zygarde, as they are offensively overwhelmed by Pokemon such as Taunt Calm Mind Arceus formes, Life Orb Yveltal, and Primal Kyogre, which easily exploit the passive structures that result from this pairing. Calm Mind Arceus-Dark is sufficient Ultra Necrozma counterplay while also using Pokemon that beat Zygarde such as special utility Giratina-O, Life Orb Yveltal, and wallbreaker Eternatus to set up itself.

  • Defensive or Swords Dance utility Primal Groudon provides a Primal Kyogre switch-in and entry hazards. Primal Groudon is also able to beat Dondozo via Overheat and eases the burden on Zygarde by excellently checking Zacian-C, which can muscle through a chipped Zygarde. Both Giratina-O and Ho-Oh provide hazard control as well as status support and phazing. which synergize to create a strong defensive backbone capable of supporting most offensive Pokemon.

  • As Zygarde is deadweight against stall, stallbreakers such as Choice Specs Lunala, Choice Band Rayquaza, and defensive Primal Kyogre are great allies that also decimate bulkier balance teams, which easily contain Zygarde. However, Zygarde does not require a dedicated stallbreaker, as Pokemon such as Taunt Calm Mind Arceus formes and wallbreaker Eternatus more than suffice if they're positioned properly. Zacian-C is also a good option due to its ability to blanket check Taunt Arceus formes, which hinder Zygarde, while being a fast Pokemon and a thorn in the side of hyper offense teams, which can overwhelm Zygarde. As Zacian-C is similarly futile against stall, more dedicated stallbreakers are recommended alongside this duo.

Dragon Dance.description:
• Dragon Dance Zygarde is among the most threatening setup sweepers available, benefitting from its gargantuan bulk and access to the extremely valuable Thousand Arrows to break through the opposing team. Thousand Arrows hits crucial targets like Primal Groudon, Ho-Oh, and Eternatus. Grounding airborne targets is fantastic and renders would-be checks like Ho-Oh and Yveltal unable to fulfill their roles properly.

  • Substitute lets Zygarde set up on passive walls like Chansey, Gothitelle, and Giratina reliably. It also eases the activation of Power Construct and blocks status, which is especially useful against Ho-Oh's Sacred Fire and Primal Groudon's Toxic.

  • Dragon Tail grants a powerful phazing tool to force out what would otherwise be hard checks and counters like Dondozo, defensive Tera Grass Ho-Oh, and Coil Zygarde. Against Ho-Oh in particular, Zygarde outruns it once boosted and can use Dragon Tail before it uses Whirlwind. Glare ruins aggressive switches from Pokemon like Arceus-Ground, Arceus-Dark, and Marshadow that would attempt to offensively check it.

  • Leftovers grants Zygarde appreciated recovery, which is especially useful against passive foes such as defensive Ho-Oh, Chansey, and Blissey that fail to break its Substitute. Zygarde can also opt for Groundium Z to turn Thousand Arrows into Tectonic Rage, which lets it OHKO foes like Primal Groudon, Marshadow, and Ultra Necrozma at +1. At +2, it can even OHKO foes like defensive Arceus-Dark and Arceus-Ground after some chip damage. Alternatively, Dragonium Z with Dragon Tail allows Zygarde to get a surprise OHKO at +1 on Mega Salamence, as well as opposing defensive Zygarde after some chip damage, which would otherwise try to set up on it. Thanks to Devastating Drake having neutral priority, unlike Dragon Tail, Zygarde can easily eliminate Ditto and phazers like Giratina and opposing Dragon Tail Zygarde.

  • Investing 12 EVs in HP maximizes Leftovers recovery. Alongside 48 EVs in Special Defense, it allows Zygarde to survive one Ice Beam from defensive Arceus formes. The even HP spread also allows Zygarde to activate Power Construct after only two Substitutes if using a Z-Crystal. Investing 232 EVs in Speed lets Zygarde outrun Eternatus at +1 after Power Construct.

  • Tera Ground is the premier Tera type when running Leftovers, further boosting Thousand Arrows and allowing it to almost always OHKO Marshadow at +1 while 2HKOing fast support Arceus-Ground. It also turns Zygarde's 4x weakness to Ice into a 2x weakness, which is especially relevant against defensive Arceus formes like Arceus-Ground and Arceus-Water.

  • Zygarde can also opt for a defensive Tera type. With Tera Fairy, it becomes immune to Dragon, blocking any attempt at phazing it from the likes of Giratina and opposing Dragon Tail Zygarde. Tera Water can be used to turn the tables against defensive Primal Kyogre thanks to granting Zygarde a resistance to both Scald and Ice Beam. Removing its weakness to Fairy also allows Zygarde to set up one more time against the likes of Zacian-C and Arceus-Fairy and retaliate harder with a boosted Thousand Arrows.

  • Dragon Dance Zygarde is a good choice on bulky offense teams looking for a good way to disrupt and clean the opposing team once it has been chipped down.

  • It's preferable to keep this Zygarde set unrevealed before attempting to set up. In particular, this set works best if the opponent is forced to Terastallize a non-Tera Fairy Pokemon, like Tera Grass Ho-Oh, so Zygarde can spam Dragon Tail with ease.

  • Another good strategy is to reveal Substitute early to activate Power Construct and then attempt to sweep later in the game once Zygarde has been made much more bulky thanks to its ability.

  • Due to the fact that this set trades off its defensive aspect for more offensive power, a good defensive core is often required to address setup sweepers before Zygarde can find an opportunity to set up itself. Primal Kyogre, defensive Ho-Oh, and Arceus-Dark all help to deal with common setup sweepers like Primal Groudon, Arceus-Ground, and Ultra Necrozma.

  • Wallbreakers like Choice Band Marshadow, special Ultra Necrozma, and Rayquaza can help chip away at Tera Fairy physical walls like Roar Giratina, defensive Zygarde-C, and Dondozo that this set cannot break nor phaze once they have Terastallized.

Trapper.description:
• Zygarde-C's gargantuan bulk, effective boosting options, and great attacking moves make it a top-tier physical wall and sweeper.

  • Thousand Waves allows Zygarde to trap its foe, and given its limited list of checks and its ability to flip matchups with Terastallization, it can often use the target as setup fodder and sweep through the opposing team by trapping otherwise decent checks, like non-Taunt Arceus formes and Eternatus. In the event that Zygarde can't set up, it can still pivot to a teammate after trapping its foe.

  • Dragon Dance and Coil boost Zygarde's mediocre Attack to threatening levels. The former's Speed boost lets it avoid having to run Scale Shot, while the latter's Defense boost gives Zygarde an easier time setting up on Attack-boosting foes, such as Zacian-C and Arceus.

  • Thousand Arrows should be used with Dragon Dance, providing Zygarde with the means to hit foes immune to Ground like Ho-Oh and Giratina-O. Scale Shot should be used with Coil, hitting the aforementioned foes while boosting Zygarde's Speed, with Coil reversing Scale Shot's Defense-lowering effect.

  • 80 HP EVs let Zygarde always survive defensive Arceus-Water's Ice Beam, letting it safely activate Power Construct against it, while 204 Attack EVs and an Adamant nature let Zygarde always OHKO defensive Ho-Oh at +6 Attack. The remaining EVs are dumped into Defense to make Zygarde as physically bulky as possible, helping it take attacks from foes such as Ho-Oh and Primal Groudon. If Zygarde isn't running Thousand Arrows, a spread of 248 HP / 48 Def / 80 SpD / 132 Spe with a Careful nature lets Zygarde avoid a 2HKO from Mega Mewtwo Y's Psystrike and an OHKO from Life Orb Deoxys-A's Psycho Boost after Stealth Rock while letting Zygarde-C always outspeed Choice Scarf Yveltal at +2.

  • Terastallization is extremely potent on Zygarde, letting it set up on foes it otherwise couldn't by replacing its exploitable weaknesses to Ice, Dragon, and Fairy. Tera Water notably gives Zygarde a resistance to Water and Ice, letting it set up on Primal Kyogre and non-Taunt Arceus-Water. Tera Poison turns Zygarde's Fairy weakness into a resistance, letting it set up on Zacian-C.

  • A large part of this Zygarde's effectiveness is a result of its surprise factor, luring in checks such as non-Taunt Arceus formes and turning them into setup fodder. Zygarde is often reliant on Terastallization to accomplish this, so players should carefully consider the need to Terastallize their other Pokemon if they wish to preserve Zygarde's sweeping potential.

  • Players should typically try getting Zygarde to below 50% HP to activate Power Construct. This can be achieved by letting a trapped foe weaken Zygarde, or by letting it get worn down by residual damage and stray hits. However, Zygarde's HP should be carefully managed, given that Rest only has 8 PP and renders Zygarde passive during its sleep turns.

  • Entry hazard setters such as Primal Groudon, utility Arceus formes, and Eternatus can weaken the opposing team, letting Zygarde-C OHKO foes such as defensive Arceus formes with Thousand Waves.

  • Wallbreakers such as Primal Kyogre and Necrozma-DM can soften up foes such as opposing Zygarde and Arceus formes, letting it sweep more easily.

Lead.description:
• Mega Diancie is a great lead for offense teams thanks to its STAB combination that threatens the main Defoggers in the metagame, which include Ho-Oh, Giratina-O, and Yveltal, combined with its ability Magic Bounce, which allows it to serve as an anti-lead to all other suicide leads in the tier, notably including Deoxys-S, Shuckle, Smeargle, and Glimmora.

  • Once Mega Diancie can't do much else in the field, Explosion allows it to KO itself, wear down a foe, and let an ally safely come in afterwards. Earth Power is an alternative to OHKO Glimmora and situationally hit common switch-ins in Primal Groudon, Zacian-C, and Necrozma-DM.

  • The given EV spread lets Mega Diancie avoid an OHKO from Choice Band Tera Flying Rayquaza's Dragon Ascent and Choice Band Marshadow's Low Kick after Stealth Rock as well as a 2HKO from Life Orb Yveltal's Dark Pulse while ensuring that it outspeeds neutral-natured foes with base 120 Speed, such as Palkia-O and Mega Salamence, on top of OHKOing specially offensive Yveltal with Moonblast.

  • Especially against non-hyper offense teams, if at Team Preview it's clear that Mega Diancie's relative lack of Speed and frail nature for the metagame may render it outsped and OHKOed, it should be kept for the mid-game, where it can come into foes such as Yveltal, Ho-Oh, and Giratina-O to force a switch while setting at least one entry hazard.

  • Mega Diancie has significantly higher bulk before Mega Evolving, so it may be desirable to Mega Evolve it later on to withstand an attack such as unboosted Mega Salamence's Earthquake or defensive Arceus-Ground's Judgment. In very niche scenarios where Sticky Web manages to get into its side of the field, preserving Diancie's Mega Evolution to keep Clear Body for the mid-game can help preserve Diancie's Speed. Clear Body can also be used to avoid being hindered by Glimmora's Mud Shot, but this also can let Glimmora lay entry hazards instead in the event of an incorrect prediction.

  • Faster foes such as Zacian-C, offensive Arceus-Water, and Deoxys-A can prevent Mega Diancie from doing anything by immediately OHKOing it. Allies such as Primal Groudon, Yveltal, and Necrozma-DM act as good partners to mitigate this issue by providing alternatives to play around them.

  • Mega Diancie can become setup fodder to foes such as Necrozma-DM, Primal Groudon, and Zacian-C. Ditto is a solid partner to punish setup sweepers and mitigate the potential vulnerability to them.

Wallbreaker.description:
• Mega Diancie's unique typing allows it to be a powerful mixed wallbreaker in the tier, since its coverage is quite difficult to pivot around for standard defensive structures, which include Pokemon such as Ho-Oh, Zygarde, Arceus-Dark, Yveltal, and Giratina-O. Mega Diancie typing also has niche defensive utility, allowing it to soft-check Yveltal, Rayquaza, and unboosted Mega Salamence. Its ability in Magic Bounce plays a vital role against hyper offense structures barring Trick Room, since being able to deny entry hazard leads such as Deoxys-S, Smeargle, and Shuckle, effectively anti-leading them, is great for defensive partners such as Primal Groudon and support Arceus formes that cannot hold Heavy-Duty Boots. Mega Diancie is also fantastic against stall because of this ability, since it counters Giratina and non-Sludge Bomb Eternatus. This role compression makes Mega Diancie a fantastic tool for bulky offense teams that need a Pokemon that does well against all playstyles in the tier if positioned correctly.

  • Earth Power is necessary to hit Primal Groudon, Necrozma-DM, and Zacian-C super effectively, allowing Mega Diancie to punish them for recklessly switching in.

  • Substitute enables Mega Diancie to ease prediction against potential switches, as well as giving Mega Diancie the chance to wallbreak further thanks to the Substitute protecting it from faster threats such as Arceus-Ground and Zacian-C. Substitute also lets Mega Diancie block Nuzzle from Smeargle, effectively walling it while denying Sticky Web. Alternatively, since Mega Diancie is able to beat all the common Defoggers in the tier, including Ho-Oh, Giratina-O, and Yveltal, it makes for a powerful Stealth Rock user, as it is able to make progress against a predicted switch from Arceus-Dark or Rayquaza. Spikes is also a viable option, but Mega Diancie's poor longevity means it cannot stack multiple Spike layers throughout a game consistently, even if the second layer aids greatly in wallbreaking similarly to Stealth Rock.

  • The default EV spread allows Mega Diancie's Diamond Storm to 2HKO Lunala after Stealth Rock, and OHKO Choice Band Tera Fire Rayquaza. Mega Diancie's SpA EVs enable Moonblast to OHKO defensive Zygarde after a layer of Spikes, and to 2HKO Dondozo, with Earth Power also 2HKOing defensive Primal Groudon. The defensive investment avoids a 2HKO from Chi-Yu's Flamethrower after Stealth Rock, and from offensive Ho-Oh's Brave Bird, all while also outspeeding neutral-natured base-120 Speed Pokemon such as Arceus, Mega Salamence, and Palkia-O. The alternate spread enables Mega Diancie to also avoid an OHKO from Pheromosa's Triple Axel, but it shouldn't be used alongside Substitute as it has an even amount of HP, which hinders the usage of such move.

  • Mega Evolving Diancie should be done as soon as possible to make the most out of Magic Bounce, which is needed to bounce back status conditions from Giratina-O, Alomomola, and Eternatus, as well as deny entry hazards from Ferrothorn and Primal Groudon, even if the latter is quite risky due to Mega Diancie's poor bulk. It should be noted that Mega Diancie can induce mind games against Mud Shot Glimmora when anti-leading it, since Clear Body pre-Mega Evolution protects Diancie from Mud Shot's Speed drop, meaning Mega Diancie can decide not to Mega Evolve to more easily 2HKO Glimmora and deny it from setting up entry hazards. This process is quite risky to pull off though, since it is effectively a coinflip as to whether Glimmora uses Stealth Rock or Mud Shot.

  • Although Mega Diancie can easily switch Ho-Oh and remove it via Diamond Storm, it should be careful around Ho-Oh, since Sacred Fire possibly burning Mega Diancie is a massive hinderance to its wallbreaking capabilities, especially against stall teams, where Pressure from Giratina and Eternatus quickly drains Diamond Storm's limited PP. Diamond Storm should not be recklessly spammed, as its needed to actually break through these cores in stall and bulky balance teams.

  • Mega Diancie struggles against Primal Groudon, Dragon Dance Necrozma-DM, Zacian-C, and Primal Kyogre, since they are all able to withstand its attacks and OHKO it back with ease, or in Zacian-C's case, it can outspeed and set up on it first. On the bulky offense teams Mega Diancie fits well on, a defensive backbone is essential to control these threats. Zygarde is able to control Primal Groudon with ease; Tera Water sets can also contain Dragon Dance Necrozma-DM for Mega Diancie, while Tera Fairy variants shut down Dragon Dance Zygarde, which is able to use Mega Diancie as setup fodder thanks to Tera Ground removing its Moonblast weakness. Yveltal can either utilize Choice Scarf to revenge kill Dragon Dance Necrozma-DM and boosted Zacian-C for Mega Diancie, or it can use its Life Orb set with Sucker Punch to revenge kill Ultra Necrozma and Deoxys-A for Mega Diancie; Yveltal and Mega Diancie additionally form a potent wallbreaking duo for the team. Finally, defensive Primal Groudon can form a strong entry hazard-stacking core with Mega Diancie, while Mega Diancie beats Giratina-O for it. Offensive Primal Groudon sets appreciate Mega Diancie setting entry hazards for it to more easily wallbreak. Both Primal Groudon sets are able to handle Zacian-C and Primal Kyogre for Mega Diancie.

  • Choice Scarf Yveltal is an especially good teammate, since it can pivot into Mega Diancie via U-turn, which is an important need for Mega Diancie due to its poor bulk. Yveltal can pivot Diancie in against bulkier foes such as Coil Zygarde and defensive Ho-Oh that switch in place of Dragon Dance Necrozma-DM. Another pivoting teammate includes Landorus-T, which checks Zacian-C and Dragon Dance Arceus-Ground for Mega Diancie while letting Mega Diancie run Substitute or Spikes, as Landorus-T commonly runs Stealth Rock. Life Orb Yveltal and other offensive teammates such as Choice Band Marshadow and Meteor Beam Eternatus appreciate Mega Diancie setting entry hazards for them to break through defensive cores more easily, with the latter two Pokemon also appreciating Mega Diancie pressuring stall teams early on for them to clean up afterwards.

Sticky Web Lead.description:
• Ribombee sets itself apart from other Sticky Web leads thanks to its excellent matchup against all Sticky Web leads. In addition to this, Ribombee has a valuable Speed tier and great ability in Shield Dust. Its Speed tier allows it to outspeed common Taunt users such as Arceus formes and Yveltal. Thanks to Shield Dust, Ribombee can stay in against Smeargle to serve as a status absorber for teammates. However, since Ribombee is unable to deny entry hazards from Deoxys-S and Glimmora leads, it is a niche anti-Sticky Web lead on hyper offense teams.

  • Imprison allows Ribombee to prevent leads such as Smeargle and Shuckle from setting Sticky Web. Skill Swap allows Ribombee to bypass Magic Bounce from Mega Diancie in order to set Sticky Web. In addition, it also provides utility in stealing Primordial Sea and Desolate Land from Primal Kyogre and Primal Groudon, respectively, allowing teammates such as Zacian-C to tank an Origin Pulse and Yveltal to take Heat Crash better.

  • Stun Spore is a nuisance for the majority of the tier such as Arceus formes, Yveltal, and Ho-Oh due to Ribombee's Speed tier. It is especially valuable against Ho-Oh, as it prevents Ho-Oh from freely Defogging. In addition, Stun Spore cripples threats such as Zacian-C and Eternatus, preventing them from using Ribombee to easily set up. Moonblast is an option to allow Ribombee to KO Smeargle without risking status for a switch-in. In addition, Moonblast directly threatens Yveltal, Giratina-O, and Dragon Dance Zygarde.

  • The given EV spread is for Moonblast sets and allows Ribombee to outspeed all base 120s while maximizing Moonblast damage. For example, it can always 2HKO physical Giratina-O. The secondary EV spread also allows Ribombee to outspeed all base 120s while the defensive investment turns Ferrothorn's Power Whip, Dragon Dance Zygarde's Thousand Arrows, and Fezandipiti's Alluring Voice into 4HKOs.

  • Tera Steel allows Ribombee to block Mortal Spin from Smeargle and Glimmora in order to maintain Sticky Web. However, since the use cases are rare, Ribombee should not usually Terastallize. It is also wise to wait for Smeargle to reveal Mortal Spin before Terastallizing, as sets carrying Rapid Spin will cause Ribombee to waste the Terastallization.

  • Ribombee is an excellent anti-Sticky Web choice thanks to its excellent matchup against Smeargle and Shuckle. However, its lead matchups against threats such as Mega Diancie, Deoxys-S, and Glimmora are more challenging. If Ribombee has a bad lead matchup, such as against Deoxys-S or Grimmsnarl, it can wait to set Sticky Web later thanks to its excellent Speed tier. Ribombee can also be preserved if it survives after setting Sticky Web. This is useful so that it can serve as a sack to bring a teammate in or used to revenge kill threats such as Yveltal.

  • Pokemon that appreciate Sticky Web support such as Zacian-C, wallbreaker Primal Kyogre, specially offensive Yveltal, and Chi-Yu are excellent teammates. Zacian-C can easily run through bulkier offense teams and appreciates the ability to outspeed opposing Zacian-Cs. Primal Kyogre is able to greatly threaten Arceus formes and Eternatus thanks to Sticky Web support. Specially offensive Yveltal appreciates being able to outspeed checks such as Zacian-C and Arceus formes. In return, Yveltal provides devastating breaking power and an unmatched ability to keep Sticky Web. Chi-Yu greatly gains from Sticky Web support slowing down checks such as Arceus-Dark and -Fairy. In exchange, Chi-Yu provides the most devastating wallbreaking power in the tier and greatly aids the matchup versus stall teams. Extreme Killer Arceus and Dragon Dance Arceus-Ground are both excellent teammates for Ribombee. Arceus is able to blow through walls such as Primal Groudon and Zygarde with Double Edge while soft-checking Marshadow with Sticky Web support. Arceus-Ground is an excellent answer to Zacian-C and Double Dance Primal Groudon, which can easily threaten to reverse sweep; in addition, it also threatens Ho-Oh.

  • Due to Ribombee's inability to deny entry hazards, Pokemon that are weak to Stealth Rock such as Chi-Yu and Mega Salamence should be picked sparingly as teammates. The exception to this is Yveltal, as its ability to keep Sticky Web up is too valuable. Eternatus is extremely valuable as a teammate due to its ability to absorb Toxic Spikes, as they can cripple hyper offense teammates such as Arceus, Primal Groudon, and Primal Kyogre. Extreme Killer Arceus can easily set up on Ribombee, so Marshadow and Zacian-C are appreciated in order to check it. Although Ribombee can annoy Ho-Oh with Stun Spore, it cannot prevent Ho-Oh from Defogging, so Pokemon that threaten Ho-Oh out such as Meteor Beam Eternatus or can Taunt it such as Tera Fire specifically offensive Yveltal are appreciated.

Psychic Terrain Setter.description:
• Despite being relatively slow and having underwhelming stats compared to the rest of the tier, Tapu Lele's Psychic Surge can be incredibly useful to many powerful Psychic-types, increasing their power while protecting them from otherwise-crippling priority such as Sucker Punch from Yveltal, Shadow Sneak from Marshadow and Giratina-O, and Extreme Speed from Arceus.
  • Taunt prevents slower Pokemon such as Ho-Oh from using Defog against Tapu Lele and also stops entry hazards from setters such as Primal Groudon, Necrozma-DM, and Glimmora. This can be particularly handy against Smeargle, as blocking it from setting Sticky Web prevents foes from outspeeding teammates such as Deoxys-A and Ultra Necrozma.
  • Moonblast threatens Dark-types such as Yveltal and Arceus-Dark, preventing them from aggressively switching into Tapu Lele or anti-leading against it, and the move also hits Giratina-O for a good amount of damage to dissuade it from switching into Tapu Lele, especially if it has already been dealt chip damage from a teammate.
  • Either Psyshock or Psychic can be used to threaten most switch-ins that don't really mind Moonblast, particularly Eternatus and Primal Groudon; Psychic hits harder and hits Pokemon like Primal Groudon, but Psyshock does more damage to specially defensive Pokemon like Ho-Oh, Chansey, and Calm Mind Arceus formes.
  • Nature's Madness makes it unsafe for virtually any Pokemon, including Chansey and Ho-Oh, to sit on Tapu Lele in an attempt to stall out Psychic Terrain turns, allowing it to unconditionally weaken such foes if they are left in and possibly even put them into OHKO range for its other moves.
  • Terastallizing Tapu Lele should only be done if absolutely necessary, as many Psychic Terrain sweepers strongly value Tera. Tera Normal can allow Tapu Lele to defeat Marshadow one-on-one in a pinch and blank Deoxys-A's Shadow Ball and Lunala's Moongeist Beam, which can be particularly handy when facing opposing Psychic Terrain and Ditto. Tera Steel can work to block Mortal Spin from Glimmora, which can be particularly handy when Tapu Lele is paired with Sticky Web. Tera Fairy lets Tapu Lele's Moonblast OHKO offensive Yveltal while doing a strong amount of damage to defensive ones, and it lets Tapu Lele relatively easily handle Arceus-Dark by itself by giving it a resistance to its STAB move and doing extremely heavy damage to it.
  • While Tapu Lele has usable Special Attack and benefits from Psychic Terrain itself, its power pales in comparison to Pokemon such as Deoxys-A and Ultra Necrozma, so it should stay in for as few turns as possible to maximize the number of turns teammates have to use Psychic Terrain. However, even though its bulk and typing are sufficient to let it switch into many attacks, Tapu Lele's lack of pivot and self-sacrifice moves along with the general fraility and common shared weaknesses of most potential teammates can turn this into a double-edged sword after it is sent in; it can sometimes get stuck on the field for multiple turns after coming in, consuming precious turns of Psychic Terrain without being able to meaningfully make progress, and it can also become setup fodder for Dragon Dance Ultra Necrozma and Arceus-Ground. As such, achieving maximum turns of Psychic Terrain often involves risky play that leads to either sacrificing Tapu Lele or, because there is value to preserve Tapu Lele later to reset Psychic Terrain, a teammate. To minimize this, opportunities to save a suicide lead, if run, after it has set entry hazards by switching Tapu Lele into attacks that it can survive such as Sacred Fire from Ho-Oh, Low Kick from Marshadow, and Judgment from support Arceus formes and immediately switching back into the lead on the next attack can beneficial for this purpose.
  • Preserving Tapu Lele in stall matchups can allow it to stallbreak with Nature's Madness and Taunt.
  • When resetting Psychic Terrain, it can be appropriate to just use Tapu Lele as death fodder against offensive teams, as it only needs to survive entry hazard damage to set Psychic Terrain, allowing teammates to use the maximum amount of Psychic Terrain turns. However, there is some merit in switching it into priority moves, particuarly against common Choice Band users such as Rayquaza and Marshadow. This dynamic can also dissuade priority users from using priority moves even if Psychic Terrain is not active for fear of giving Tapu Lele a safe switch to reset the Terrain for free yet again.
  • It may be useful to keep Tapu Lele in if it can do something meaningful, such as using Taunt to prevent opposing entry hazards, Defog, or setup from slower Speed boosters such as Rock Polish Primal Groudon and Dragon Dance Necrozma-DM.
  • Tapu Lele's influence comes from the Pokemon it enables. Meteor Beam Deoxys-A is the biggest beneficiary of Psychic Terrain, as it deeply appreciates priority protection of all sorts due to its nonexistent bulk while often taking out Pokemon such as Ho-Oh and Yveltal with its Meteor Beam, at which point it can spam an absurdly powerful Expanding Force that is sufficient to OHKO almost everything it hits neutrally at +1, including defensive Primal Groudon, offensive Arceus formes, offensive Primal Kyogre, and Terastallized Eternatus. Additionally due to the Psychic Terrain, Deoxys-A being less reliant on Tera to avoid priority makes it even easier to fit onto teams. Ultra Necrozma's bulk in base forme, powerful Light That Burns the Sky, and ability to set up with Dragon Dance complement the general fast, frail special attackers otherwise used as teammates, warding against counterplay in specially defensive Pokemon like Ho-Oh and Primal Kyogre while not being overly reliant on Psychic Terrain to sweep like Expanding Force users. Ultra Necrozma also particularly enjoys protection against Marshadow's Shadow Sneak and Yveltal's Sucker Punch and the potential of teammates and Tapu Lele itself to threaten Yveltal and Arceus-Dark.
  • Glimmora can also be a good teammate, as it is very consistent at setting various entry hazards to put bulkier Pokemon such as Arceus formes into OHKO range for teammates while preventing opposing hazards and threatening Ho-Oh and Yveltal with its Power Gem. Alternatively, while they are less consistent at getting Stealth Rock up, Sticky Web from setters such as Smeargle and Shuckle may provide some added insurance against opposing opposing speedy or otherwise dangerous threats such as Deoxys-A, Ultra Necrozma, Zacian-C, and Booster Energy Flutter Mane. Sticky Web can be particularly helpful in allowing for the freer use of potential teammates such as Lunala, Basculegion, and Mega Mewtwo Y while also potentially freeing up team members such as Deoxys-A to not run Speed-boosting natures for more power. Ditto may be appropriate to handle Speed boosters such as Arceus-Ground as well as Sticky Web sweepers.

Choice Specs.description:
• Choice Specs Lunala is an excellent wallbreaker on bulky offensive or balance teams. Its combination of Moongeist Beam and Moonblast allows it to OHKO or 2HKO a majority of the tier, with only a few exceptions such as Ho-Oh and defensive Primal Kyogre. Blissey and Chansey also cannot get 2HKOed, but they are more niche. It can muscle through defensive Pokemon, sponging neutral hits with ease because it possesses high natural bulk for an offensive Pokemon. With Tera Ghost, no viable Pokemon in the tier can safely switch into it.
  • Moonblast is invaluable to Lunala, as it makes Dark-types a shaky switch-in. It 2HKOes defensive Yveltal and Arceus-Dark, and it has a high roll to OHKO specially offensive Yveltal. Moonblast can also be used as a midground option if the opposing team has a Dark-type in order to ease prediction.
  • Unlike Psychic, Psyshock allows Lunala to chunk Pokemon with high Special Defense, such as defensive Primal Kyogre and Ho-Oh. Psyshock also OHKOes defensive Eternatus after Stealth Rock and a single layer of Spikes. Another big advantage to Psyshock is that it allows Lunala to save PP on its Moongeist Beam while still dealing meaningful damage.
  • Trick allows Lunala to punish defensive Pokemon like Ho-Oh and defensive Yveltal that otherwise freely switch into it. This does come with the caveat of making it unable to 2HKO Pokemon like Arceus-Fairy, defensive Primal Groudon, defensive Necrozma-DM after Tera, and Zygarde after Tera once it loses its Choice Specs. It also misses out on OHKOing offensive Necrozma-DM, offensive Eternatus, and Giratina-O.
  • Tera Ghost enhances Lunala's wallbreaking potential. After Tera, it is now able to consistently 2HKO Ho-Oh and specially offensive Yveltal. It also gains the ability to OHKO offensive Primal Groudon while also 3HKOing Arceus-Dark, making it unable to switch in. Tera Ghost also provides defensive merit to Lunala, as without the extra weakness to Ghost and Dark, it can now tank a Hex from special utility Giratina-O, a Foul Play from defensive Arceus-Dark, and a Poltergeist from Life Orb Marshadow without Shadow Shield. At full HP, Lunala is able to tank a Poltergeist from Tera Ghost Life Orb Marshadow, a Poltergeist from Choice Band Marshadow, a Dark Pulse or Knock Off from Tera Dark specially offensive Yveltal, and a Poltergeist from Giratina-O.
  • Tera Fairy is also an option to consider over Tera Ghost. Terastallizing into a Fairy-type gives it an outstanding defensive typing, This also provides Lunala the capacity to take hits from Arceus-Dark, Giratina-O, Marshadow, and Yveltal, as well as allowing it to OHKO defensive Yveltal and Arceus-Dark with Moonblast. Tera Fairy should be considered on bulky offense teams that may lack the backbone to handle Lunala's threats.
  • Lunala thrives against bulkier team structures. It is able to punish defensive Pokemon fairly reliably given the right prediction. Unfortunately, hyper offense teams have Pokemon that tend to overwhelm Lunala. Being Choice-locked allows Pokemon like Zacian-C, Arceus, and Ultra Necrozma a free setup opportunity, conceding momentum. If Shadow Shield remains intact, Lunala can often trade with some Pokemon such as offensive Primal Groudon, Ultra Necrozma, and Zacian-C. Otherwise, Lunala is reliant upon its teammates during these matchups.
  • Lunala struggles against the tier's Ghost- and Dark-types, so having defensive Pokemon that are able to handle them means that Lunala's potential as a wallbreaker can be fully materialized. On a balance or bulky offense team structure, Coil Zygarde, defensive Arceus-Fairy, and defensive Arceus-Dark are three such examples that help assist in dealing with Pokemon that would otherwise capitalize on Lunala, such as Marshadow, Yveltal, physical utility Giratina-O, Arceus-Dark, and Ho-Oh.
  • Pokemon that synergize well with Lunala offensively can punish foes that otherwise brush off Lunala's hits. Zacian-C used in conjunction with Lunala can create an excellent offensive core on bulkier teams. Lunala deals with Primal Groudon, Dondozo, Necrozma-DM, and Alomomola, which otherwise check Zacian-C. Zacian-C supports it in return by dealing with Marshadow and Yveltal. Choice Band Rayquaza can also be considered as an offensive partner due to its ability to 2HKO Ho-Oh and defensive Primal Kyogre.

Meteor Beam.description:
• Meteor Beam Lunala is an essential wallbreaker on Psyspam teams that works in conjunction with other Pokemon such as Meteor Beam Deoxys-A and Ultra Necrozma to overwhelm shared counterplay such as Arceus-Dark and Yveltal. Despite appearing to be a good option as a standalone wallbreaker for balance and bulky offense, it should only be used on Psyspam teams; without the full support of a Psyspam team, Meteor Beam Lunala is outclassed by other wallbreakers such as Eternatus and specially offensive Yveltal, which are more consistent and require little support to be effective wallbreakers. These Pokemon, Eternatus in particular, are substantially more difficult to revenge kill due to their defensive typing and higher Speed.
  • Meteor Beam is used to OHKO Pokemon that would otherwise wall Lunala such as Yveltal and Ho-Oh. The Special Attack boost provided by Meteor Beam makes it difficult to check Lunala defensively; for example, defensive Primal Groudon and utility Arceus formes are 2HKOed by +1 Moongeist Beam, while defensive Primal Kyogre and Ho-Oh are 2HKOed by +1 Psyshock in Psychic Terrain.
  • Moongeist Beam and Psyshock provide strong neutral coverage. Moonblast rounds out Lunala's moveset and makes Dark-types such as Yveltal, Arceus-Dark, and Chien-Pao hesitate to swith in. Psyshock is run over Psychic to enable Lunala to deal with special walls such as Ho-Oh and more niche Pokemon such as Chansey that shrug off Moongeist Beam.
  • Lunala frequently utilizes Tera Fairy for defensive purposes and to wallbreak for its teammates. Tera Fairy enables it to effortlessly remove one of the biggest threats to Psyspam teams, Choice Scarf Yveltal. Since Yveltal poses no threat to it after Tera, Lunala can opt to OHKO with either Meteor Beam and get a boost or with Tera Fairy Moonblast after Stealth Rock. Additionally, +1 Tera Fairy Moonblast OHKOes utility Arceus-Dark after Stealth Rock.
  • Lunala is best used as a mid-game wallbreaker. It often uses Tera Fairy to remove Pokemon that can be a headache to Psyspam teams, such as Yveltal, Arceus-Dark, and Marshadow. Using Tera to remove these threats is a worthwhile expenditure, as this often enables teammates such as Deoxys-A and Ultra Necrozma to sweep.
  • Tapu Lele is a mandatory teammate to set Psychic Terrain. Tapu Lele's Moonblast also relieves Lunala of some of the burden of handling Dark-types such as Yveltal and Arceus-Dark. Glimmora is commonly used as a dedicated lead, as it can consistently set and remove entry hazards to keep Shadow Shield intact. Additionally, Smeargle and Shuckle can be used instead of or alongside Glimmora to provide Sticky Web support to enable Lunala to outspeed Pokemon such as Marshadow, Eternatus, and Zacian-C.
  • Deoxys-A and Ultra Necrozma round out an offensive core that is difficult for many teams to withstand. Deoxys-A provides speed control to help with Pokemon such as Chien-Pao and Zacian-C, and it also provides a second Meteor Beam that can be useful in case Lunala misses or when the opposing team has multiple targets such as Ho-Oh and Yveltal. Ultra Necrozma adds a physical attacker and a potent win condition after a Dragon Dance. Furthermore, it has some resilience to Ditto, as it needs to be heavily chipped to be revenge killed. Additionally, Ditto makes an excellent teammate itself, as it can revenge kill boosted threats such as Dragon Dance Arceus-Ground and Rock Polish Primal Groudon, which can easily slice through Psyspam teams if given an opportunity to boost.

Offensive Pivot.description:
• Pheromosa is a solid offensive pivot with good role compression thanks to its blazing Speed tier, massive Attack stat, and useful utility in Rapid Spin. Pheromosa is a good fit on balance teams that need a fast wallbreaker or pivot that can check Deoxys-A. However, due to its frailty, weakness to priority, and middling typing, Pheromosa does require a lot of support to fill its role effectively.
  • Triple Axel provides essential coverage against Yveltal, Eternatus, and Giratina-O while also denying entry hazards against Smeargle and Deoxys-A leads by breaking their Focus Sash and removing them from play.
  • Rapid Spin allows Pheromosa to take advantage of the many switches it forces by clearing hazards for teammates such as specially offensive Yveltal and Mega Salamence.
  • Choice Band makes it difficult for opposing Pokemon to switch in against Pheromosa, as Necrozma-DM and Alomomola on a roll are 2HKOed by Close Combat, Giratina-O and Eternatus are 2HKOed by Triple Axel while defensive Yveltal risks the OHKO from it, and wallbreaker Primal Kyogre is OHKOed by Close Combat after Stealth Rock.
  • Tera Fighting skyrockets Pheromosa’s wallbreaking power, as now even Dondozo, defensive Primal Groudon, and offensive Eternatus are 2HKOed by Close Combat. Tera Fighting also guarantees an OHKO on Arceus-Dark.
  • Tera Ghost prevents Extreme Speed from Arceus and Rayquaza, allowing Pheromosa to revenge kill them more consistently. Tera Normal blocks Shadow Sneak from Marshadow and Giratina-O, so it can revenge kill Marshadow and KO a weakened Giratina-O more efficiently.
  • Pheromosa is useful at breaking holes in the opposing team and chipping walls such as Giratina-O and Necrozma-DM early-game. It is best to mostly use U-turn early-game to scout Terastallizations it can force from foes such as Arceus-Dark and Zygarde. Pheromosa is also an excellent late-game cleaner once Ho-Oh and parts of defensive cores such as Giratina-O and Primal Groudon are removed.
  • Teams with defensive cores including Pokemon such as Giratina-O, Primal Groudon, Eternatus, and Necrozma-DM can collectively wall Pheromosa and punish wrong predictions. It is best to continually use U-turn to chip down these cores without the possibility of losing momentum, although Rocky Helmet Necrozma-DM can heavily punish this. In that case, it is best to have a teammate such as specially offensive Yveltal with Knock Off pressure Necrozma-DM instead. Pheromosa also needs to be wary of Choice Scarf Yveltal, as this set can unexpectedly snipe it off with Oblivion Wing.
  • Pheromosa needs solid defensive teammates to tank attacks from opposing threats like Necrozma-DM and Yveltal after it pivots out such as Primal Groudon, Arceus-Fairy, and Ho-Oh. Pheromosa also appreciates teammates that can hard switch into Extreme Speed from Arceus and Shadow Sneak from Marshadow, such as Giratina-O and Yveltal.
  • Gothitelle is an excellent teammate, as it can trap Ho-Oh, which Pheromosa struggles to make progress against. In addition, Gothitelle can trap parts of defensive cores such as defensive Primal Groudon and Eternatus, allowing Pheromosa to more easily pressure the rest of the team.
  • Pheromosa can often use U-turn to scout switch-ins and put a teammate in an excellent position. Setup sweepers that take advantage of its positioning such as Double Dance Primal Groudon, Arceus-Ground, and Mega Salamence make excellent teammates. These Pokemon can easily gain a free turn of setup by threatening out typical Pheromosa switch-ins such as Ho-Oh, Eternatus, and Necrozma-DM.

Ultra Dragon Dance.description:
• Necrozma-DM's incredible stats in both formes, excellent offensive movepool, and powerful boosting option in Dragon Dance make it one of NatDex Ubers's premier sweepers.

  • Earthquake targets Steel-types such as opposing Necrozma-DM and Zacian-C and also hits Primal Groudon for super effective damage.

  • Stone Edge OHKOes Ho-Oh, which can tank any of +1 Necrozma-DM's other moves except Light That Burns the Sky and either phaze it or use Sacred Fire to hit it pre-Ultra Burst for super effective damage and threaten both formes with a burn. Sunsteel Strike targets Fairy-types such as Arceus-Fairy, and it's especially powerful when it has STAB pre-Ultra Burst. Outrage is an alternative, offering Ultra Necrozma a powerful STAB attack that can hit Dark-types like Yveltal and Arceus-Dark for huge damage, but leaving Necrozma locked into the move makes it a niche option.

  • Light That Burns the Sky provides +1 Ultra Necrozma with the means to OHKO foes such as offensive Arceus formes and defensive Ho-Oh, though Necrozma-DM cannot use it before or on the turn it Ultra Bursts.

  • A spread of 40 HP / 248 Atk / 80 Def / 140 Spe allows Ultra Necrozma to outspeed Chi-Yu unboosted and Choice Scarf Yveltal at +1. The physical investment enables Ultra Necrozma to avoid an OHKO from +2 Arceus's Extreme Speed after Spikes and Choice Band Marshadow's Shadow Sneak after switching into Stealth Rock as Necrozma-DM. The special bulk enables Necrozma-DM to avoid a OHKO from +1 Eternatus's Fire Blast after Stealth Rock.

  • An alternate spread of 16 HP / 192 Atk / 168 Def / 132 Spe allows as Ultra Necrozma to outspeed Yveltal, avoid a OHKO from specially offensive Yveltal's Sucker Punch, and OHKOes defensive Zygarde with +1 Light that Burns the Sky after Stealth Rock.

  • A more situational spread of 16 HP / 244 Atk / 24 Def / 224 Spe with a Jolly nature allows Ultra Necrozma to outspeed Marshadow and Arceus formes unboosted, and avoids an OHKO as Ultra Necrozma from Choice Band Marshadow's Shadow Sneak, and Chien-Pao's Ice Shard after a layer of Spikes, and as Necrozma-DM from Tera Dark Yveltal's Sucker Punch after Stealth Rock, but the loss in bulk over other spreads is noticeable, for example being OHKOed as Ultra Necrozma from +2 Life Orb Arceus's Extreme Speed as Ultra Necrozma.

  • Necrozma-DM best fits on offense teams looking for an exceptionally powerful sweeper that can set up on common offensive threats like Zacian-C.

  • Choosing when to Ultra Burst is essential to letting Necrozma-DM sweep. Doing so provides Ultra Necrozma with the ability to outspeed the entire unboosted metagame and many boosted threats when at +1, such as the likes of Zacian-C and +2 Rock Polish Primal-Groudon, foes a +1 Necrozma-DM fails to outspeed. However, Necrozma-DM's defensive profile becomes considerably worse when it Ultra Bursts, losing bulk, Prism Armor, and many of its resistances, notably exchanging its resistances to Fairy and Ice for weaknesses. However, the loss of its weaknesses to Fire and Ground, notably gaining a resistance to the former, does help Necrozma-DM better take on foes such as Primal Groudon. Gaining a resistance to Water also allows Ultra Necrozma to have an easier time handling Primal Kyogre. Additionally, the increase in Necrozma-DM's power, notably against foes weak to its moves thanks to Neuroforce, and access to Light That Burns the Sky make Ultra Necrozma a more potent wallbreaker.

  • Necrozma-DM enjoys support from entry hazard setters like Deoxys-S, which can wear down foes such as Arceus-Dark and Primal Groudon. Dual screens setters like Grimmsnarl are notably helpful for allowing Necrozma-DM to set up very easily on common attackers like Zacian-C and Eternatus.

  • Fellow wallbreaking and sweeping teammates such as Zacian-C and Arceus can help break holes in the opposing team for Necrozma-DM by eliminating or weakening foes such as Arceus-Dark and Ho-Oh, or they can sweep using the holes it creates breaking through bulky foes such as Primal Groudon and support Arceus formes.

Dragon Dance.description:
• Dragon Dance Necrozma-DM is a ferocious wallbreaker and cleaner that finds a home on bulky offense and balance teams. Necrozma-DM is able to leverage its bulk, typing, ability, and the possbility of bluffing the threat of Ultra Necrozma to force a switch or absorb an incoming attack such as Primal Groudon's Precipice Blades or Arceus-Dark's Foul Play and then use Dragon Dance.

  • If Ho-Oh is sufficiently covered, Stone Edge can be substituted for Photon Geyser. This move still hits Ho-Oh hard while enabling Necrozma-DM to beat Dondozo, which would otherwise wall it. It has the added benefit of OHKOing Eternatus without the need to spend a turn stat boosting.

  • Solganium Z allows Necrozma-DM to OHKO common switch-ins such as Arceus-Dark, Yveltal, and Zygarde with +1 Searing Sunraze Smash mid-game, clearing the way for its teammates.

  • The extra bulk provided by 132 HP EVs allows Necrozma-DM to avoid OHKOs from some hits it otherwise wouldn't while still hitting important Speed benchmarks. For example, Necrozma-DM will survive Life Orb Marshadow's Poltergeist after Stealth Rock, defensive Primal Groudon's Precipice Blades after a single layer of Spikes, and defensive Primal Kyogre's +1 Scald. With 124 Speed EVs, Necrozma-DM has the ability to outspeed uninvested base 90s with a neutral nature such as defensive Primal Groudon and Ho-Oh. At +1 Necrozma-DM outspeeds fully invested Yveltal. At +2 Necrozma-DM outspeeds nearly the entire unboosted metagame, only fearing priority moves such as Marshadow's Shadow Sneak or Yveltal's Sucker Punch.

  • Alternatively, investing in 236 Speed EVs allows Necrozma-DM to outspeed fully invested base 120s at +1 such as Arceus-Ground and Mega Salamence. If Necrozma-DM uses Dragon Dance on the switch-in, it retains the ability to OHKO Mega Salamence with Searing Sunraze Smash with minimal chip after Intimidate removes Necrozma-DM's Attack boost.

  • A third EV spread of 88 HP / 252 Atk / 16 Def / 4 SpD / 148 Spe with an Adamant nature outspeeds Zygarde, avoids a OHKO from +1 defensive Primal Kyogre's Scald, and after Stealth Rock a OHKO from Arceus-Dark's Foul Play.

  • Due to a lack of recovery, Necrozma-DM needs to be cognisant of its HP, as any chip is permanent. Necrozma-DM frequently absorbs large hits while setting up or revenge killing certain threats, and taking chip may render it unable to do so. For example, Necrozma-DM always survives defensive Primal Groudon's Precipice Blades after a layer of Spikes but can be OHKOed if Stealth Rock is also on the field.

  • Dragon Dance Necrozma-DM should not be used to fulfill the defensive duties typically associated with Necrozma-DM such as switching into an unscouted Zacian-C, though it can revenge kill them. It excels when used as a secondary check to them, with teammates such as Ho-Oh and Primal Groudon serving as primary checks.

  • Necrozma-DM struggles heavily against offensive Primal Groudon, Marshadow, and physical Arceus-Ground. Offensive Primal Groudon is able to OHKO Necrozma-DM with its STAB moves. Marshadow is always able to revenge kill Necrozma-DM with Shadow Sneak and OHKO it with Poltergeist. Physical Arceus-Ground OHKOes Necrozma-DM with Tectonic Rage and can threaten to sweep if given the opportunity to use Dragon Dance. Zygarde is an excellent teammate on balance teams that can switch into all three of these Pokemon and provides valuable paralysis support, which allows Necrozma-DM to outspeed the entire unboosted metagame. Giratina-O is a good teammate on bulky offense teams that can switch into Primal Groudon and Arceus-Ground. Necrozma-DM also appreciates the Defog and status support provided by Giratina-O.

  • Arceus-Fairy provides a Dark switch-in on balance teams, which helps mitigate the downside of misfiring Searing Sunraze Smash into the wrong target. It is a good check to Life Orb Yveltal, which is otherwise very threatening to balance teams and can revenge kill Necrozma-DM with Sucker Punch. Arceus-Fairy can also provide Stealth Rock and status support in the form of Will-O-Wisp and Toxic to chip opposing Pokemon into range of Necrozma-DM's attacks such as Primal Groudon, Zacian-C, and Arceus-Ground.

Defensive.description:
• Necrozma-DM's excellent defensive typing, great stats, and movepool enable it to switch into many very powerful metagame threats, such as Mega Mewtwo Y, Deoxys-A, Eternatus, and Zacian-C, and fill utility roles to support its team, such as spreading status conditions and setting Stealth Rock.

  • Sunsteel Strike is a decent STAB move that hits Zacian-C, Giratina-O, and the Arceus formes. Earthquake hits foes that Necrozma-DM checks harder, like Zacian-C, Eternatus, and opposing Necrozma-DM, but it makes Necrozma-DM weaker in general and especially to foes that are immune to the move, such as Yveltal, Giratina-O, and Mega Salamence.

  • Toxic allows Necrozma-DM to cripple checks such as Primal Groudon, offensive Arceus-Ground, Giratina-O, and Ho-Oh. Thunder Wave is an alternative to cripple Pokemon that it checks such as Eternatus, Deoxys-A, and support Arceus formes lacking Refresh and provide speed control for its allies.

  • Knock Off allows Necrozma-DM to cripple foes by removing their item; in particular, it punishes Ho-Oh switching in to remove entry hazards.

  • As Necrozma-DM has multiple ways to punish hazard removal attempts from Ho-Oh and Giratina-O, it is a solid Stealth Rock setter.

  • The given EV spread avoids a 2HKO from Zacian-C's Close Combat after Intrepid Sword, Life Orb Deoxys-A's Shadow Ball after Stealth Rock, and defensive Arceus-Ground's Judgment.

  • Leftovers increases Necrozma-DM's longevity, notably cancelling out chip damage from Stealth Rock. Rocky Helmet is an alternative that prevents Zacian-C from trying to overwhelm Necrozma-DM's Morning Sun PP by wearing it down.

  • Necrozma-DM is a Pokemon that does not Terastallize often, as its innate typing already lets it handle a good portion of the metagame. After Terastallizing, Necrozma-DM becomes unable to properly check foes it's meant to cover, and its allies often make better use of the mechanic. Tera Poison lets Necrozma-DM check Zacian-C more consistently even if it Terastallizes and absorb Toxic Spikes from Eternatus. Tera Water alternatively allows Necrozma-DM to remove its regular type weaknesses and gain Fire and Water resistances, allowing it to come into Arceus-Ground, Primal Kyogre, Ho-Oh, and Primal Groudon in a pinch.

  • Necrozma-DM can be used early-game to wall foes such as Mega Mewtwo Y, Zacian-C, and Eternatus and then either cripple them or set Stealth Rock, but it shouldn't be heavily relied on, as it can get worn down and be left unable to check them consistently.

  • As it's used to handle several metagame threats such as Zacian-C and Deoxys-A, Necrozma-DM can get easily overwhelmed; therefore, it appreciates allies that can be secondary checks to such foes like Primal Groudon and Ho-Oh.

  • Multiple foes such as Primal Groudon, Ho-Oh, Yveltal, and Marshadow can threaten Necrozma-DM, so it appreciates allies to check them, with defensive examples including Arceus-Fairy and Zygarde and offensive ones including Palkia-O, Primal Kyogre, and Arceus-Ground; Necrozma-DM, in return, checks foes that would force them out such as Eternatus and Zacian-C.

  • Being crippled by burn, paralysis, or Knock Off from foes such as Ho-Oh, Zygarde, and Ferrothorn can compromise Necrozma-DM's consistency at checking foes; therefore, it makes a good defensive core with support Arceus formes with Refresh and Primal Groudon.

Ultra Stealth Rock.description:
• Ultra Necrozma's ability to masquerade as defensive Necrozma-DM enables it to lure and remove switch-ins such as Primal Groudon and Ho-Oh, which makes it an attractive option for teams in search of an offensive Stealth Rock setter.

  • Earth Power is used to 2HKO defensive Primal Groudon and Dragon Dance Necrozma-DM. Stone Edge is used primarily to lure and OHKO Ho-Oh and also threatens Yveltal switching in, as it is 2HKOed.

  • The given EV spread enables Ultra Necrozma to OHKO Eruption Primal Groudon after Stealth Rock with Earth Power and defensive Eternatus after Stealth Rock with Photon Geyser. Additionally, the given EV spread enables Photon Geyser to avoid activating Glimmora's Toxic Debris when used prior to Ultra Bursting. The defensive investment enables Ultra Necrozma to survive Choice Band Marshadow's Shadow Sneak.

  • Stealth Rock Ultra Necrozma works best as a lead, but in some games, other options are preferable. Regardless, Ultra Necrozma aims to set Stealth Rock early on and lure in typical counterplay to defensive Necrozma-DM such as Ho-Oh, Primal Groudon, and Zygarde. Additionally, Ultra Necrozma can also use Light That Burns the Sky to OHKO physically bulky Pokemon such as Zygarde, support Arceus formes, and Giratina-O before fainting.

  • If entry hazard removal is desired, Choice Scarf Yveltal is a good fit on faster teams due to compressing the roles of a Defogger, a pivot and a revenge killer to Pokemon that threaten Ultra Necrozma such as Marshadow, Arceus, and Zacian-C. Giratina-O is also an option, as it can tailor its moveset to disrupt opposing teams through status while dealing respectable damage and appreciates Ultra Necrozma's ability to remove Pokemon that annoy it such as Ho-Oh and Arceus-Fairy.

  • As Ultra Necrozma struggles heavily with Yveltal, Calm Mind Arceus-Dark or Arceus-Fairy are excellent teammates that provide a sturdy defensive switch-in and appreciate Ultra Necrozma's ability to handle Primal Groudon and Ho-Oh. Alternatively, Zacian-C is an option for more aggressive teams that also revenge kills Marshadow while providing speed control.

  • Eternatus is a great teammate due to absorbing and setting Toxic Spikes while also serving as a soft check to specially offensive Yveltal. In return, Eternatus appreciates Ultra Necrozma's ability to handle Primal Groudon, Zygarde, and Arceus-Ground.

All-Out Attacker.description:
• A combination of great offensive stats, almost unresisted STAB moves, and great coverage make Marshadow a powerful wallbreaker in offensive teams, capable of overwhelming many foes including Zygarde, Necrozma-DM, and Arceus-Dark. This set is best suited for offensive teams looking for a fast and powerful wallbreaker and cleaner.

  • Spectral Thief steals the opponent's boosts, which is useful for scaring out targets such as Calm Mind Arceus-Ground and Coil Zygarde. It also bypasses Substitute, which is valuable for baiting and eliminating foes like Swords Dance Arceus-Ground attempting to use Marshadow as setup fodder. Alternatively, Ice Punch eliminates defensive Zygarde, as Poltergeist followed up by Ice Punch has a high chance to KO while preventing transformation if Zygarde switches out to scout. Otherwise, Rock Tomb deals with Ho-Oh and is a great tool to deny Mega Salamence's attempts to setup. Hidden Power Ice alongside a Naive nature always OHKOs defensive Zygarde after Spectral Thief's damage as well as Mega Salamence.

  • Poltergeist is Marshadow's strongest Ghost-type STAB move, capable of 2HKOing foes such as defensive Necrozma-DM and Primal Kyogre.

  • Low Kick is preferred over Close Combat due to the heavy weight of most foes Marshadow will face, reaching its maximum base power of 120 against staples like Arceus, Primal Groudon, and Necrozma-DM, making it a consistent STAB move without drawbacks.

  • Shadow Sneak is able to finish weakened targets that are otherwise faster than Marshadow like Ultra Necrozma, Zacian-C, and Eternatus.

  • Tera Ghost is the best option on Marshadow, further boosting its STAB options and allowing it to 2HKO defensive Arceus-Ground and Primal Groudon with Poltergeist after Stealth Rock damage, and also ensuring it always OHKOs Ultra Necrozma after Stealth Rock with Shadow Sneak. Losing its weakness to Fairy-type attacks is also useful against Arceus-Fairy, allowing Marshadow to survive its Judgment and use another attack. Losing its resistance to Dark-type can be detrimental, however, as Yveltal can threaten to OHKO Marshadow with Sucker Punch.

  • Life Orb maximizes its damage output without locking its moves like Choice Band. Due to the recoil, Marshadow is at risk of being chipped rapidly, so a Spell Tag can be used instead. The loss in power compared to Life Orb is significant, however, making Marshadow unable to KO many key targets, like Arceus-Fairy, Arceus-Ground, and Necrozma-DM.

  • It is particularly good to bring Marshadow early-game because it can threaten foes such as Arceus-Dark, Necrozma-DM, and Ho-Oh with its STAB moves and coverage. Marshadow is valuable because its moves are particularly hard to switch into, allowing it to make progress against most teams if it's well positioned.

  • Entry hazards and passive damage are extremely valuable for this set, making entry hazards setters such as Primal Groudon and Eternatus valuable teammates. These Pokemon also form a defensive core that can deal with utility Arceus-Fairy, a foe that Marshadow has trouble breaking through without using Terastallization.

  • Setup sweepers like Arceus-Ground, Arceus-Fairy, and Ultra Necrozma appreciate Marshadow's ability to chip key walls like Zygarde, Necrozma-DM, and Arceus-Dark, so they can clean a weakened team. In return, Arceus-Ground and Ultra Necrozma can handle Primal Groudon, while Arceus-Fairy can deal with Choice Scarf Yveltal, two Pokemon that Marshadow has trouble threatening.

Bulk Up.description:
• With Bulk Up increasing its already great Attack stat; a STAB combination no viable Pokemon resists; great STAB options in Poltergeist, Low Kick, Spectral Thief; and a strong priority move in Shadow Sneak further boosted by Technician, Bulk Up Marshadow is an incredible mid- to late-game wallbreaker and cleaner that can threaten a great majority of the metagame.

  • Spectral Thief is a fantastic tool that not only steals boosts from common boosted threats such as Coil Zygarde, the many Calm Mind Arceus variants, and slow Dragon Dance Necrozma-DM variants but also threatens these targets for huge damage. Alternatively, Poltergeist can be used for its higher Base Power; this comes in handy with Tera Ghost, as it can OHKO defensive Primal Kyogre at +1 after Stealth Rock damage for example.

  • Low Kick perfectly complements Marshadow's Ghost-type attacks and forms a nearly unresisted STAB combination. Due to the heavy weight of Pokemon in Ubers, Low Kick is preferred to Close Combat because it has no drawbacks while still having 120 Base Power against common targets like Primal Groudon, Primal Kyogre, Arceus, and Arceus-Dark.

  • Shadow Sneak is a powerful tool that can eliminate Speed-boosted and naturally faster targets such as Deoxys-A, as well as weakened Dragon Dance Arceus-Ground and Ultra Necrozma.

  • Tera Ghost is the premier choice because it further amplifies Marshadow's damage output. In particular, it allows Poltergeist to OHKO defensive Necrozma-DM at +1, OHKO Dragon Dance Zygarde at +1 and—after Stealth Rock damage—almost always 2HKO defensive Arceus-Fairy when unboosted. Turning into a pure Ghost-type also comes in handy in order to tank one hit from the likes of Arceus-Fairy and Ultra Necrozma.

  • Life Orb is the best item in order to maximize the damage Marshadow can deal. Spell Tag can also be used, granting its Ghost-type attacks a 20% damage boost with no drawbacks. The drop in power is significant, however; for example, Spell Tag Marshadow is not guaranteed to 2HKO defensive Primal Groudon at +1 with Poltergeist.

  • A Jolly nature is generally recommended in order to ensure that Marshadow always outspeeds Arceus formes as well as Mega Salamence. An Adamant nature further boosts Marshadow's Attack, giving it a chance to OHKO defensive Necrozma-DM at +1 with Poltergeist.

  • Marshadow likes entry hazards for their ability to hinder common switch-ins such as Arceus-Fairy, Primal Groudon, and Zygarde-C; thus, Spikes support from Primal Groudon and Toxic Spikes support from Eternatus are welcome.

  • Marshadow hates switching in on entry hazards, as their damage racks up quickly when factoring its poor bulk, lack of recovery, and the possible Life Orb recoil. Thus, a Defogger like Ho-Oh or Giratina-O fits well with Marshadow. On top of that, Ho-Oh and Giratina-O can easily spread status and cripple the likes of Arceus-Fairy and Primal Groudon.

Choice Band.description:
• Choice Band Marshadow is a beacon of offensive role compression in a single slot for balance and bulky offense structures. Marshadow shores up some of the biggest holes in the defensive backbones of these structures, since it single-handedly revenge kills Extreme Killer Arceus, wallbreaker Primal Kyogre, and Ultra Necrozma. The latter is particularly important, as it allows teams to easily diversify their Arceus slot beyond Arceus-Dark. Furthermore, Marshadow's Tera Ghost Shadow Sneak is also powerful enough to serve as speed control, as it 2HKOes even offensive Eternatus and Zacian-C. Additionally, Marshadow is similarly effective against bulkier Pokemon, as the pool of Pokemon able to safely switch in long-term is limited to Coil Zygarde and Tera Fairy Garganacl. Marshadow's efficacy at revenge killing, wallbreaking, and providing speed control enables it to play an important role in most battles against most archetypes barring stall.

  • Poltergeist is Marshadow's primary wallbreaking tool, and its sheer power is a significant reason why Marshadow is so difficult to safely switch into for balance and bulky offense teams lacking Coil Zygarde or Tera Fairy Garganacl, as Poltergeist even 2HKOes defensive Ho-Oh and Timid Arceus formes. Spectral Thief is used to help dissuade setup sweepers such as Coil Zygarde and Calm Mind Arceus formes while still packing a solid punch and the ability to safely clean weakened teams. Shadow Sneak enables Marshadow to revenge kill Pokemon that outspeed it such as Deoxys-A, Zacian-C, or a boosted Ultra Necrozma. Low Kick is used over Close Combat, as it reliably reaches 120 Base Power against most foes; although Chi-Yu and Chansey are notable exceptions, Low Kick 2HKOes both anyway, and Close Combat's low PP and defense reductions, putting Marshadow in range of attacks it would otherwise survive, make it a poor option.

  • Marshadow is an excellent user of Terastallization but is by no means dependent on it to function. Rather, Tera Ghost serves to enhance Marshadow’s Marshadow's potency by reaching key damage thresholds. For example, Tera Ghost Shadow Sneak is guaranteed to OHKO Ultra Necrozma and Mega Mewtwo Y while also 2HKOing Pokemon such as offensive Eternatus and Zacian-C. Tera Ghost also pushes Poltergeist to absurd levels, enabling Marshadow to OHKO wallbreaker Primal Kyogre and Rayqauza while having favorable odds to OHKO offensive Ho-Oh. Tera Ghost Spectral Thief is powerful enough to prevent Calm Mind Arceus formes from getting out of hand, as they are now 2HKOed. Tera Ghost also has some defensive applications; shedding its Fairy weakness in a pinch can be beneficial against Arceus-Fairy or Zacian-C.

  • Marshadow's poor bulk and defensive typing leave it with scant safe switch-in opportunities. However, Marshadow's bulk is sufficient to take a hit from some Pokemon. For example, Marshadow survives Primal Groudon's uninvested Precipice Blades, Eternatus's unboosted Dynamax Cannon, and Arceus-Dark's +1 Judgment. This is at its fullest display against hyper offense structures, which is also Marshadow's best matchup, where its efficacy as a revenge killer is at full display.

  • Marshadow is still a solid revenge killer against bulky offence and balance structures, but it often transitions to a wallbreaking role. Its Spectral Thief easily halts late-game sweeping attempts from Pokemon such as Coil Zygarde and Calm Mind Arceus formes. Its combination of instant power and Speed provides insurance against +1 Dragon Dance Necrozma-DM, as other Pokemon such as Sucker Punch Yveltal and Zacian-C require a boost or significant chip damage to revenge kill it. Choice Band Marshadow struggles against stall, as it is hard checked by Dondozo, and its prediction-reliant nature makes it difficult to generate reliable progress against defensive Ho-Oh, Chansey, Giratina, and defensive Arceus-Dark. Defensive Eternatus's Toxic Spikes also poses a threat to Marshadow, limiting its switch-in opportunities.

  • Marshadow is a common addition to the common balance core of defensive Primal Groudon, offensive Ho-Oh, Coil Zygarde, and Calm Mind Arceus-Dark, as it offensively checks the biggest threats to this core in Tera Normal Double-Edge Extreme Killer Arceus and wallbreaker Primal Kyogre. This core can defensively check most of the metagame, including Pokemon that can scare Marshadow out such as Eternatus and Zacian-C. As Marshadow offensively checks Dragon Dance Necrozma-DM, Coil Zygarde can more easily justify Tera Fairy to act as a counter to Dragon Dance Zygarde, which would otherwise threaten this core, especially since boosted Tera Ground Thousand Arrows OHKOes Marshadow, preventing it from using Spectral Thief.

  • Marshadow is an excellent teammate for Arceus-Fairy,as it revenge kills Ultra Necrozma and avoids makeshift countermeasures such as Tera Dark Ho-Oh. Arceus-Fairy also provides a switch-in to Arceus-Dark and Yveltal, and its positive matchup against Coil Zygarde and Garganacl is appreciated. Defensive Primal Kyogre is common on these teams due to its stellar matchup against stall, while its bulk allows it to trade against specially offensive Yveltal and Dragon Dance Zygarde.

• Melmetal is an extremely strong wallbreaker that depends on Trick Room due to its low Speed stat. It also doubles as an excellent Extreme Killer Arceus check, which can give teammates like Primal Kyogre trouble. However, Melmetal relies on Tera in order to beat its checks and can have PP issues with Double Iron Bash.
  • Ice Punch provides valuable coverage that OHKOs Mega Salamence and Zygarde. Thunder Punch allows Melmetal to wallbreak past bulky Water types such as Dondozo, Arceus-Water, Primal Kyogre, and Alomomola while also threatening to 2HKO Ho-Oh.
  • Superpower allows Melmetal to OHKO specially defensive Ferrothorn. Ferrothorn sets with Protect can be harder to KO, though, as it will scout with Protect and switch into an appropriate answer. Earthquake allows Melmetal to 2HKO Necrozma-DM and Primal Groudon.
  • The given EV spread avoids an OHKO from Life Orb Marshadow's Low Kick, defensive Primal Kyogre's +1 Scald, and Tera Dark Yveltal's Dark Pulse after Stealth Rock. The rest is invested in Attack to maximize damage output.
  • Tera Steel skyrockets Melmetal’s wallbreaking power and invalidates previous switch-ins such as Ho-Oh, Primal Kyogre, and Necrozma-DM by turning previous 3HKOs to 2HKOs.
  • Melmetal usually only wants to use Double Iron Bash, as its coverage moves can easily be maneuvered around, so it is best to use Melmetal as a late-game sweeper once checks such as Ferrothorn, Necrozma-DM, and Zygarde have been severely chipped or removed. If used too early, Melmetal’s checks will easily stall Trick Room turns and Double Iron Bash PP. Teammates such as Primal Kyogre and Primal Groudon should use the initial Trick Room instead to wear down checks such as Alomomola and Ferrothorn for Melmetal.
  • Once Trick Room ends, it is important to switch Melmetal out to a bulky Trick Room setter such as Cresselia and Arceus, as Melmetal is easily revenge killed outside of Trick Room. In certain situations, though, it may be best to sacrifice Melmetal once Trick Room ends, such as when another sweeper is in an excellent position to sweep and a setter like Arceus needs all of its HP to set Trick Room up safely against a threat like Primal Groudon.
  • Cresselia, Hatterene, and Arceus are extremely valuable teammates that set Trick Room and provide Lunar Dance and Healing Wish support. Cresselia can switch into Ground-type attacks from Arceus-Ground and Primal Groudon for Melmetal thanks to Levitate. In addition, Cresselia provides a way to restore Double Iron Bash’s PP thanks to Lunar Dance, which Healing Wish is unable to do. This allows Melmetal to be used mid-game to weaken its checks without worrying about Double Iron Bash PP. Hatterene is an excellent lead Trick Room setter that denies entry hazards with Magic Bounce. Arceus is an extremely consistent late-game Trick Room setter due to its bulk and can revenge kill weakened opponents with Extreme Speed.
  • Melmetal can struggle to break past bulky Steel-types such as Ferrothorn and Necrozma-DM, so Primal Groudon is an excellent teammate. Primal Kyogre is also very helpful, as it helps break past bulky Water-types such as Dondozo, Tera Water Zygarde, and Alomomola, which Melmetal and other Trick Room staples cannot break past. Calyrex-I also does well with Melmetal, as the two have similar checks such as Necrozma-DM, Alomomola, Dondozo, and Tera Water Zygarde. Both Calyrex-I and Melmetal can wear down their shared checks and position the other to sweep. However, there is an opportunity cost of running Calyrex-I over Primal Groudon or Primal Kyogre. Without Primal Groudon, Ferrothorn can waste Trick Room turns and spam Leech Seed without much risk, while without Primal Kyogre, Tera Water Zygarde can easily wall the entire team after a Coil.

Trick Room Lead.description:
• Thanks to access to Healing Wish and an anti-entry hazard ability in Magic Bounce, Hatterene is the lead for Trick Room teams. Thanks to its low Speed, it can easily use Healing Wish or deal respectable damage under Trick Room to reduce passivity.
  • Dazzling Gleam allows Hatterene to punish threats such as Zygarde and Mega Salamence that would otherwise easily set up on it. This often can bait out Tera Water or Fairy from Zygarde, allowing teammates such as Primal Kyogre and Melmetal to take advantage of this.
  • Nuzzle allows Hatterene to cripple threats that would attempt to set up on it such as Zacian-C and Necrozma-DM that hasn’t used Ultra Burst yet. However, it may make threats such as defensive Primal Kyogre faster than teammates such as Primal Groudon and Calyrex-I under Trick Room. Mystical Fire prevents Calm Mind Arceus formes from setting up on Hatterene. It also greatly threatens Ferrothorn, which gives many Trick Room team trouble. In addition, it 2HKOes Zacian-C and deals respectable damage to Dragon Dance Necrozma-DM, discouraging setup and leaving both of them in range to be KOed by Tera Ice Glacial Lance Calyrex-I and Tera Steel Double Iron Bash Melmetal.
  • The given EV spread maximizes Hatterene’s Special Attack to threaten Pokemon like Zygarde and Mega Salamence while avoiding a 2HKO from Dragon Dance Zygarde's Thousand Arrows.
  • Tera Ghost allows Hatterene to escape trapping from Gothitelle. This is useful in situations where Magic Bounce would be useful throughout the game, such as when the opponent has a persistent entry hazard setter such as Ferrothorn. In most cases, Hatterene does not need to Tera and instead should save it for teammates such as Melmetal and Calyrex-I that need it to break past their checks.
  • Hatterene should be used as a designated lead. On turn 1, Trick Room should be used almost always to take advantage of its Focus Sash and minimize risk of failing to set up. Against Pokemon that don’t immediately threaten it, such as Zygarde and Ferrothorn, Hatterene can instead use Dazzling Gleam or Mystical Fire to weaken these threats or force a Tera. On turn 2, Hatterene should usually use Healing Wish to create momentum and provide support for its teammates. However, it may be best to stay in against entry hazard leads such as Glimmora and defensive Primal Groudon. This allows Hatterene to punish these leads for using Spikes or Stealth Rock predicting Hatterene would use Healing Wish.
  • Hatterene’s ability to deny entry hazards early-game is essential for Trick Room teams, especially as most don’t have a form of hazard removal. This is significant for Calyrex-I, as it is harder for Extreme Speed Arceus and Shadow Sneak Marshadow to revenge kill it. Primal Groudon and Primal Kyogre also appreciate this, as Eruption and Water Sprout being at full power greatly aids them in wallbreaking.
  • Pokemon that appreciate Trick Room support such as Primal Groudon and Primal Kyogre make excellent teammates. Calyrex-I is an essential bulky and strong wallbreaker on Trick Room teams that greatly benefits from Hatterene keeping Stealth Rock off the field for it.
  • Hatterene needs other Trick Room setters as teammates, as it isn’t sufficient to facilitate sweepers throughout the game, so Cresselia and Arceus make excellent partners.

Dual Screens.description:
• Grimmsnarl distinguishes itself from Deoxys-S with the ability to pivot with Parting Shot, giving it better longevity while letting teammates set up easier. Grimmsnarl also has a good defensive typing versus Chien-Pao and Marshadow, both of which can revenge kill Grimmsnarl's teammates, making it a decent switch-in. Unfortunately, Grimmsnarl is unable to do much if it does get Taunted itself by Magic Coat Deoxys-S, and because it's unable to prevent Yveltal from using Defog or Calm Mind Arceus-Dark and Chi-Yu from setting up alongside it, Grimmsnarl can become passive against certain team structures; regardless, Grimmsnarl is still good at setting up dual screens for hyper offense teams.
  • Taunt is useful to ensure opposing Pokemon like Arceus, Primal Groudon, Zacian-C, and Zygarde cannot set up alongside Grimmsnarl as it sets dual screens. It's also useful to prevent opposing leads such as Glimmora and Smeargle from setting up entry hazards, letting Grimmsnarl protect its teammates.
  • Parting Shot allows Grimmsnarl to pivot, increasing momentum while allowing for easier setup for the teammate with its stat drops. Spirit Break prevents Yveltal and Arceus-Dark from completely walling Grimmsnarl while also stopping the latter from setting up alongside Grimmsnarl. Thunder Wave is a niche option that allows Grimmsnarl to punish foes like Meteor Beam Eternatus, Arceus-Fairy, and Zacian-C more directly, benefitting its teammates to let them sweep more easily while avoiding a potential sweep.
  • The given special bulk investment allows Grimmsnarl to survive defensive Primal Groudon's Overheat, with the rest of the EVs being dumped into Defense to survive attacks such as 300-Base Power Basculegion-M's Last Respects and Arceus-Ground's unboosted Tectonic Rage without Reflect. However, with both screens up, Grimmsnarl can survive attacks such as Zacian-C's Play Rough and Eternatus's +1 Sludge Bomb.
  • Tera Ghost allows Grimmsnarl to avoid getting hit by Arceus's Extreme Speed, which is useful for slowing down its attempt to sweep through Grimmsnarl's team, allowing it to set up Reflect more reliably. However, Grimmsnarl's teammates are better off using Terastallization, since they benefit from it more. Grimmsnarl should only Terastallize in emergency situations.
  • It is usually best to lead with Grimmsnarl to set up screens early for the team. If there is an opposing Arceus-Dark or Yveltal present though, it may be desirable to lead with something else, such as Eternatus, and play more aggressively with Grimmsnarl around them to ensure that Grimmsnarl isn't direct setup fodder for them. A similar idea applies against Shuckle, since Grimmsnarl cannot deny Sticky Web from going up due to Mental Herb.
  • It's important to set the correct screen against a foe. Physical threats like Marshadow and Rayquaza should be dealt with Reflect, while special threats like Arceus-Fairy and Palkia-O are dealt with Light Screen. This is necessary to ensure Grimmsnarl can set both screens up as opposed to just one, since it will never be OHKOed behind the correct screen.
  • Grimmsnarl works best on hyper offense teams that can capitalize on the extra longevity provided by dual screens, giving them multiple setup opportunities. Dragon Dance Arceus-Ground can reliably take care of Zacian-C and Necrozma-DM, both of which would be an issue for Grimmsnarl, while also having Taunt and Stone Edge to prevent Defog users from removing dual screens. Kyurem-B has a similarly good matchup versus standard Defog users such as Ho-Oh and Giratina-O while also having a good matchup against Dondozo, something Grimmsnarl cannot help with against stall teams because it cannot provide hazard control. It also appreciates the additional bulk to let it set up with Dragon Dance twice, notably letting it outspeed Zacian-C.
  • Teammates that can generally dissuade hazard removal options like Ho-Oh, Giratina-O, and Yveltal are great for Grimmsnarl.
